commit_message:
Fix using of public address with SSL for Neutron

Neutron public endpoint should use public ssl hostname

Change-Id: Ibbc5430495ddc4d1408a517517b658b93b2e0eea
Related-bug: #1478649
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/17/206517/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: public_vip = Noop.hiera('public_vip') public_ssl = Noop.hiera_structure('public_ssl/services', false) if public_ssl public_address = Noop.hiera_structure('public_ssl/hostname') public_protocol = 'https' else public_address = public_vip public_protocol = 'http' end auth_name = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/auth_name', 'neutron') password = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/keystone/admin_password') tenant = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/tenant', 'services') region = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/region', 'RegionOne') service_name = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/service_name', 'neutron') admin_address = Noop.hiera_structure('management_vip') configure_endpoint = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/configure_endpoint', true) configure_user = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/configure_user', true) configure_user_role = Noop.hiera_structure('quantum_settings/configure_user_role', true) internal_address = admin_address it 'should declare neutron::keystone::auth class' do should contain_class('neutron::keystone::auth').with( 'password' => password, 'auth_name' => auth_name, 'configure_endpoint' => configure_endpoint, 'configure_user' => configure_user, 'configure_user_role' => configure_user_role, 'service_name' => service_name, 'public_address' => public_address, 'public_protocol' => public_protocol, 'admin_address' => admin_address, 'internal_address' => internal_address, 'region' => region, )
deleted_lines: it 'should set empty trusts_delegated_roles for neutron auth' do contain_class('neutron::keystone::auth')

commit_message:
Refactor Haproxy_backend_status

* Clean the code up
* Improved debugging

Change-Id: Ie1ba15e2f40c903efdf970447676987a14156ed4
Related-Bug: 1449219
Related-Bug: 1459357
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/31/179131/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'should accept correct retry count, step and timeout value' do type = Puppet::Type.type(:haproxy_backend_status).new( { :name => 'test', :socket => '/var/run/haproxy.sock', :step => '200', }) expect(type[:step]).to eq(200) expect { Puppet::Type.type(:haproxy_backend_status).new( { :name => 'test', :socket => '/var/run/haproxy.sock', :step => 'all', }) }.to raise_error type = Puppet::Type.type(:haproxy_backend_status).new( { :name => 'test', :socket => '/var/run/haproxy.sock', :timeout => '200', }) expect(type[:timeout]).to eq(200) expect { Puppet::Type.type(:haproxy_backend_status).new( { :name => 'test', :socket => '/var/run/haproxy.sock', :timeout => 'all', }) }.to raise_error
deleted_lines: it 'should accept correct retry count value' do

commit_message:
Fix bug 1474876 - Use subnet_id in CalculateDelta

Change network_tasks.py to use get_network(subnet_id) function
Change unit-test TestNetworkTasks:test_calculate_delta

Change-Id: I32a12147e73362a6def767316d78e43ed982b88c

This fix is to implement access-level both for CIFS and NFS share

commit_message:
Add access-level support in VNX Manila driver

Manila framework adds a new blueprint to set access-level for a share so
that admin can grant read-only/read-write permission to specific share.
This fix is to implement access-level both for CIFS and NFS share
in VNX Manila driver.

Change-Id: Ib651300978c451ca9b0d4b768c1f06d44d51a951
Implements: bp emc-vnx-manila-driver-read-only-share

commit_message:
Add tests to not break ceilometer dispatcher

This change adds tests that inject ceilometer samples and
check that gnocchi handles them.

commit_message:
set/unset volume image metadata

This patch implements:
- Create, delete, update APIs for modifying volume image metadata.
- Refactoring in the volume API to accommodate both user and
  image metadata.
- All of the necessary testcases needed for the changes.

DocImpact
APIImpact
Partially implements: bp support-modify-volume-image-metadata
Change-Id: I22792ef7bd49c763d7c130aa8cac9abc3fff2d4c

deleted_lines: def update_volume_metadata(self, context, volume, metadata, delete=False): _metadata, delete)

commit_message:
Fix appearance and sync with latest changes

Change-Id: I06c931ece562137a1cd08d799ca70c946cd6848a
Blueprint: templates-for-networking
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-specs refs/changes/59/206159/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: to be added to support this). node. (/clusters/x/network_configuration/template/). template can be loaded/reloaded any time before deployment is started and after reset. So, it is the same behaviour as for all network settings now. Deployment serializer for networking will be selected with regard to the fact whether template was loaded or not. groups) in the DB (explained better below). If it is applied then DB data (related to network roles to networks mapping, networks to interfaces mapping and network objects topology) is ignored by networking serializer. If it is not applied then DB data is taken into account by networking serializer. Serialization of other data is not affected. If yaml was uploaded for particular nodes serialized data for them will be taken from there. Additional flag is added to node to override network part of astute.yaml. It the flag is set then network data is taken from serializer output regardless of template presence. Node's yaml overriding task can be postponed due to lack of time. (to support complex cases which cannot be configured via API, like subinterface bonding). Network roles' set can be not equal to core set, it is up to user. No verification of network roles' set is provided at this stage. Network roles to networks mapping can be set for each node role independently. Sets of network roles and networks may be different on every particular node. Validation should be added to ensure that all required roles are present on every node. It's naturally done with network roles to tasks mapping but can be postponed due to lack of time. for different node network groups. It also allows to use different NICs' sets for particular node network groups and particular nodes. networks. network roles required is declared. (It's required for template validation at least.) It can be out of first feature release as not highest priority task which takes significant time. which is required for serialization to orchestrator. metadata. It is true for both template and general flow. storage: ep: br-storage private: ep: br-prv public: ep: br-ex management: ep: br-mgmt fuelweb_admin: ep: br-fw-admin for referencing network roles required for particular task. It is also used in manifests. * default_mapping - string, name of the network to map this role be default (when template is not in use). * properties - dictionary, properties which are required for underlying network are described here, like CIDR, gateway, VIPs. e.g. neutron settings. It is in our DSL format. It will be shown in UI and could be edited there. It is passed to orchestrator as is. Nailgun doesn't process it. It will not be used in 7.0. So, it can be skipped for now. Network role description example:: id: "mgmt/vip" default_mapping: "management" properties: subnet: true gateway: false vip: - name: "vrouter" namespace: "vrouter" alias: "management_vrouter_vip" - name: "management" namespace: "haproxy" alias: "management_vip" node_roles: ["primary-controller", "controller"] VIPs can be requested in network role's description. Description of VIP includes: * name - string, it should be unique name within the environment, it cannot be skipped. * namespace - string, will be serialized to null when skipped. * alias - string, it is used in serialization of VIPs for API. We use old VIPs format for API here as it has influence on other projects (OSTF, system tests) which should be fixed. Alias is needed for core VIPs only. * node_roles - list, node roles where VIPs should be set up. It can be skipped. Its value will be set to ["primary-controller", "controller"] then.

commit_message:
Aodh: add Heat functional tests

Heat have a functional tests suite to test autoscaling with ceilometer.
Ceilometer have recently move the alarming code to a new repository,
the alarming is now provided by aodh-* service.

This job will test the heat functional tests suite against
aodh-api instead of the old ceilometer-api.

This will ensures that migration to the new service works and will
not break the heat gate in the future when we really switch to aodh.

Change-Id: I1b13c375a0820612b9db0a33358ef41dda155fa2

commit_message:
Fix alembic migration script for vpnaas

Alembic migration script 56893333aa52_fix_identifier_map_fk.py
tries to change the 'ipsec_site_conn_id' column without disabling
the 'cisco_csr_identifier_map_ibfk_1' constraint. Also, there is
no need to resize existing data with a existing fk constraint,
which would already limit it to VARCHAR(36).

Change-Id: Ie820e94b43b572ec201b4c6174a93682a6cd47ab
Closes-Bug: #1464825

commit_message:
Add tool to generate SSL certificates in Magnum.

Change-Id: Ifdbe3dbf6b534b431b3445ff774aff5c86557dc3
Partial-Implements: blueprint magnum-as-a-ca
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum refs/changes/93/199493/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2014 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from M2Crypto import ASN1 from M2Crypto import EVP from M2Crypto import RSA from M2Crypto import X509 import time def make_ca_issuer(cn): """Creates Magnum default CA issuer name. """ issuer = X509.X509_Name() issuer.CN = cn return issuer def make_cert_valid(cert, days=365): """Make a cert valid from now and til 'days' from now. :args cert: certificate to make valid :args days: number of days cert is valid for from now. """ t = long(time.time()) now = ASN1.ASN1_UTCTIME() now.set_time(t) expire = ASN1.ASN1_UTCTIME() expire.set_time(t + days * 24 * 60 * 60) cert.set_not_before(now) cert.set_not_after(expire) def make_request(bits, cn='localhost'): """Create a X509 request with the given number of bits in they key. :args bits: number of RSA key bits :args cn: common name in the request :returns: a X509 request and the private key (EVP) """ priv_key = EVP.PKey() req = X509.Request() rsa = RSA.gen_key(bits, 65537, lambda: None) priv_key.assign_rsa(rsa) req.set_pubkey(priv_key) name = req.get_subject() name.CN = cn req.sign(priv_key, 'sha1') return req, priv_key def make_cacert(): """Make a CA certificate. :returns: certificate, private key and public key. """ req, priv_key = make_request(1024) pub_key = req.get_pubkey() cert = X509.X509() make_cert_valid(cert) cert.set_issuer(make_ca_issuer()) cert.set_subject(cert.get_issuer()) cert.set_pubkey(pub_key) cert.sign(priv_key, 'sha1') return cert, priv_key, pub_key def make_cert(): """Make a certificate. :returns: a new cert. """ cert = X509.X509() make_cert_valid(cert) cert.add_ext(X509.new_extension('nsComment', 'SSL sever')) return cert def make_ca_signed_cert(cacert_file, ca_key_file, cn): """Create a certificate signed by the given CA, and with the given common name. And stores the file at given location with given name. :param cacert_file: CA certificate file :param ca_key_file: CA private key file :param cn: desired common name :returns: certificate and private key """ cert_req, priv_key = make_request(1024, cn=cn) cacert = X509.load_cert(cacert_file) ca_priv_key = EVP.load_key(ca_key_file) cert = make_cert() cert.set_subject(cert_req.get_subject()) cert.set_pubkey(cert_req.get_pubkey()) cert.set_issuer(cacert.get_issuer()) cert.sign(ca_priv_key, 'sha1') return cert, priv_key

commit_message:
Correct fcntl.flock use in Pidfile.unlock

This change corrects Pidfile.unlock[1] implementation, indeed currently
it uses fcntl.flock response as a condition but fcntl.flock is a "void"
function.

[1] neutron.agent.linux.daemon

Closes-Bug: #1472725
Change-Id: If2320f29095ed388f9f6fe59d4d9b80d04adaa85

subject: Windows iSCSI: Add CHAP authentication support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-05 09:49:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/97313445766c82911745b7f1e767ca1f71d75faa', 'message': 'Windows iSCSI: Add CHAP authentication support

This patch adds CHAP authentication support for the Windows iSCSI
driver.

One-way CHAP authentication is used, having the CHAP credentials

commit_message:
Windows iSCSI: Add CHAP authentication support

This patch adds CHAP authentication support for the Windows iSCSI
driver.

One-way CHAP authentication is used, having the CHAP credentials
generated when the iSCSI target is created.

Implements: blueprint windows-iscsi-chap

Change-Id: Iee24b74c66f72efe2a9bb2187e2a4f9d9e135872
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/81/180081/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def set_chap_credentials(self, target_name, chap_username, chap_password): try: wt_host = self._conn_wmi.WT_Host(HostName=target_name)[0] self._wmi_obj_set_attr(wt_host, 'EnableCHAP', True) self._wmi_obj_set_attr(wt_host, 'CHAPUserName', chap_username) self._wmi_obj_set_attr(wt_host, 'CHAPSecret', chap_password) wt_host.put() except wmi.x_wmi as exc: err_msg = (_('Failed to set CHAP credentials on ' 'target %(target_name)s. WMI exception: %(wmi_exc)s') % {'target_name': target_name, 'wmi_exc': exc}) LOG.error(err_msg) raise exception.VolumeBackendAPIException(data=err_msg) @staticmethod def _wmi_obj_set_attr(wmi_obj, key, value): # Due to a bug in the python WMI module, some wmi object attributes # cannot be modified. This method is used as a workaround. wmi_property = getattr(wmi_obj, 'wmi_property') wmi_property(key).set(value)

commit_message:
Add Gunicorn

This patch adds Gunicorn to the global dependencies. It's used in Kuryr
to serve a libnetwork remote driver through a Unix domain socket [1].
Originally uWSGI was a candidate but it's released under GPLv2 and
Gunicorn's license is MIT License.

Check list for new requirements:

* Is the library actively maintained?

  Yes. The last commit was made 10 days ago and it's been released
  frequently since 2010 [2].

* Is the library good code?

  Yes. It was downloaded 304,698 times in the last month [3].

* Is the library python 3 compatible?

  Yes. Python 3.x >= 3.2 is required.

* Is the library license compatible?

  Yes. It's released under MIT License.

* Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu
  latest / Fedora latest)?

  Ubuntu 14.04LTS trusy has a package which version is 17.5 [4] and RHEL6
  does 18.0 [5].

* Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
  global-requirements.txt?

  I don't think so.

[1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/204820/
[2]: http://docs.gunicorn.org/en/latest/news.html
[3]: https://pypi.python.org/pypi/gunicorn/
[4]: http://packages.ubuntu.com/trusty/gunicorn
[5]: http://rpms.famillecollet.com/rpmphp/zoom.php?rpm=python-gunicorn

Change-Id: I175893fbffaba6be2089df15b25b7bd31d5d0213
Signed-off-by: Taku Fukushima <tfukushima@midokura.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/98/204998/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Run full multinode tests against new dib images

We are checking that the new dib built images that use a minimal base
and glean to init on boot are capable of running our tests. We should be
testing the full test suite and not the smoke tests. Switch the job over
to do this.

Change-Id: Ic3984df20611691ecd0328f5d678d5b9fab5a677

commit_message:
Re-enable building of heat_repo_plugins

The building of heat_repo_plugins was disabled while upstream heat
sorted out issues w/ the contrib packages and pbr >= 0.11.0.  The
upstream fix has since gone in (see
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/179671/) so we can now continue to
build heat_repo_plugins as we were prior to pbr 0.11.0 dropping.

NOTE: heat SHA has been bumped to include the commit in review 179671.

Closes-Bug: #1453864
Change-Id: Ibeffd38fc3229ab4effc95ef256ce8af3a6ffc9f
(cherry picked from commit ed491df7ee948831c17b34a90085dd7976300499)

commit_message:
Add sidebar dynamic TOC of content

lack of sidebar navigation making it much harder to use the
documentation.

This change adds a table of contents (with a max deph of 1).

Closes-Bug: #1422454
Signed-off-by: Dave Walker (Daviey) <email@daviey.com>

commit_message:
Revert "Add temporary non voting multinode smoke jobs"

These jobs have run successfully for a few days (once you factor out the
failures related to  Ia9155bc565ad79af44d88acc06759be2bf4e5f20.

Now that we know tempest-smoke should pass in multinode, these jobs have
served their purpose. Teaching grenade how to do multinode should just
work w.r.t. to tempest-smoke (there are no 'openstack' bugs that we need
to fix first).

This reverts commit fc12a7d5e2eef0c52cf8de9b1b02b522baf310ef.

Change-Id: I895fa4574cde062a818574e9686a579a5034a19e

commit_message:
Decouple the queue and subscription

Now some parts of the subscription storage drivers is assuming
the queue_controller is in the same storage. But unfortunately,
it's not always true. This patch fixes it, but there is no new
test case involved.

Closes-Bug: #1471193

Change-Id: Ic81c928657addd4e0905c3af2b3c8321017559f5

commit_message:
Add Connector to create_export

This spec proposes adding the already existing connector
object as a parameter to the driver's create_export method.

Change-Id: I4a4447e82953de7fa445b50491a9c80bf3a37310
Implements: blueprint add-create-export-connector
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/65/202765/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Add connector object to create_export call ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/add-create-export-connector There are a good number of volume drivers in Cinder today, that are using initialize_connection to do the work of exporting a volume as a target to an initiator (nova compute host). One of the reasons that those drivers are doing that, is because the create_export method API doesn't include the connector object being passed in. This spec outlines adding the connector object to the standard volume driver API for create_export. Problem description =================== There are many drivers in Cinder today that are doing volume target exports inside of initialize_connection, instead of the create_export method. One of the reasons for this is a documented understanding of what the differences between these 2 methods is supposed to be. The other problem that prevents drivers from doing the work inside of create_export, is that create_export is missing the connector object coming from the initiator. Some backends require the connector object, which contains the initiator information, in order to export a target from their array. So, drivers end up moving all of that exporting code into initialize_connection, because that's the only driver call that has the connector object. The other issue with Cinder drivers doing the exporting of volume targets in initialize_connection, is that Nova calls initialize_connection repeatedly during other processes not involved with attaching a volume, such as live migration. Nova will call a driver's initialize_connection simply to fetch the connection_information about an exported volume, not because it wants to attach a volume. Use Cases ========= The main use case is attaching a volume. When someone calls Cinder to attach a volume, they eventually call the volume manager's initialize_connection method. The volume manager's initialize_connection method first calls create_export, with the intention of asking the driver to create a target that is exported from the array to an initiator. Then the volume manager calls the driver's initialize_connection to fetch the target information to pass back to the caller, to discover the volume showing up. Proposed change =============== The proposed change is simple. Add the already existing connector object in the call to create_export. This makes the connector object universaly available to all drivers during create_export time. Then each driver can eventually be changed by each maintainer to do the target exporting then, instead of during initialize_connection time. Alternatives ------------ We can do nothing, and ask that each driver maintainer be more careful about doing any creating of exports inside of initialize_connection if they already exist. This basically makes create_export useless and a noop for all of those drivers. I'd rather see every driver use each method as they were intended, so to make reviewing drivers more consistent accross all of Cinder. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ If driver developers move the creating of the exports into create_export, then any calls into initialize_connection should be faster, depending on the driver of course. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Once the connector object is available inside of create_export, then it's possible for drivers to migrate their existing export creation code from initialize_connection into create_export. Reviewers should also be looking for this in existing and future reviews, and not approving drivers that ignore create_export. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: walter-boring Work Items ---------- First is to update the base driver.py's create_export method. Then each other driver that defines create_export will have to accept the new connector object. Then the volume manager call to create_export will need to pass the connector. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Any and all Unit tests will need to be updated to note the new connector object parameter. Driver's unit tests will need to be updated as well. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== A lot of research has gone into this, due to the efforst of trying to make Nova live migration with cinder volumes work. There is an existing etherpad that talks about the known issues of Nova, Cinder interaction. That etherpad also lists out the Cinder drivers that have potential problems with live migration due to creating exports inside of initialize_connection. * https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/CinderNovaAPI

subject: Try luksFormat up to 3 times in case the device is in use
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-01 20:11:39.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/volume/encryptors/test_luks.py', 'nova/volume/encryptors/luks.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3aabe378b128163b0e4e443a38a8d99e8bde1006', 'message': 'Try luksFormat up to 3 times in case the device is in use

Cinder change I03f8cae05cc117e14f7482115de685fc9f3fa54a is failing for
some volume driver third party CI like NetApp iSCSI because the device
is in use when formatting the device for LUKS.

This change adds a retry counter to the luksFormat command execution
like we did in commit eef97cdf4bb7f426d7feb394ef54510db8b1656b for
closing the volume and hitting intermittent in-use issues.

Closes-Bug: #1470562
Related-Bug: #1440227

Change-Id: I0cb32a6f9fbe68ae033ad00534512aa5d82a417b
'}]
commit_message:
Try luksFormat up to 3 times in case the device is in use

Cinder change I03f8cae05cc117e14f7482115de685fc9f3fa54a is failing for
some volume driver third party CI like NetApp iSCSI because the device
is in use when formatting the device for LUKS.

This change adds a retry counter to the luksFormat command execution
like we did in commit eef97cdf4bb7f426d7feb394ef54510db8b1656b for
closing the volume and hitting intermittent in-use issues.

Closes-Bug: #1470562
Related-Bug: #1440227

Change-Id: I0cb32a6f9fbe68ae033ad00534512aa5d82a417b

'}, {'number': 22, 'created': '2015-07-09 22:52:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/5c9b22bbd01170d29db160b76130f62c9409a960', 'message': 'Enable python34 tests for nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test*.py

nova/pci/stats.py:
  need to specify a key parameter which is a function that returns
  a sorting key. since we already have a pool_cmp function, added a
  shim (cmp_to_key) to reuse it
nova/scheduler/filters/trusted_filter.py
nova/scheduler/host_manager.py
  needed list() so we could delete stuff inside the loop in py3
nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_filter_scheduler.py
  needed the import of test as some tests were failing in py3,
  added noqa as test is not explicitly referenced within the
  module
nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler_options.py
  need BytesIO for py3, StringIO will fail in many tests
nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler_utils.py
  message is not available in py3, so we need to adjust
  use test.nested already added in a previous commit
nova/utils.py
  use reduce from six and explicitly typcast version_int as
  an integer

Change-Id: Ic862873f38767f12b990a030b5812ae50a44c4d0

  if we have a key which is a list, treat it just like a set
nova/utils.py
  use reduce from six and explicitly typcast version_int as
  an integer

commit_message:
Enable python34 tests for nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test*.py

nova/pci/stats.py:
  need to specify a key parameter which is a function that returns
  a sorting key. since the original intention with pool_cmp was to
  sort by number of items in each pool, we just use key parameter
  with a lambda
nova/scheduler/filters/trusted_filter.py
nova/scheduler/host_manager.py
  needed list() so we could delete stuff inside the loop in py3
nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_filter_scheduler.py
  needed the import of test as some tests were failing in py3,
  added noqa as test is not explicitly referenced within the
  module
nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler_options.py
  need BytesIO for py3, StringIO will fail in many tests
nova/tests/unit/scheduler/test_scheduler_utils.py
  message is not available in py3, so we need to adjust
  use test.nested already added in a previous commit
nova/test.py
  if we have a key which is a list, treat it just like a set
nova/utils.py
  use reduce from six and explicitly typcast version_int as
  an integer

Change-Id: Ic862873f38767f12b990a030b5812ae50a44c4d0

subject: libvirt: update docstring in blockinfo module for disk_info
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-06 18:18:59.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/blockinfo.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/6207eaa3dcebe2a34295cc488ecbc61bb8faa8fd', 'message': "libvirt: update docstring in blockinfo module for disk_info

The docstring was listing disk_info as a tuple but it's a dict in the
code and it wasn't pointing out that boot_index is an optional field.

Long-term we should probably convert disk_info into an object (doesn't

commit_message:
libvirt: update docstring in blockinfo module for disk_info

The docstring was listing disk_info as a tuple but it's a dict in the
code and it wasn't pointing out that boot_index is an optional field.

Long-term we should probably convert disk_info into an object (doesn't
need to be versioned, but would be cleaner as an object). I started
doing this with a namedtuple but the format and boot_index fields being
optional makes namedtuple a bit messy.

Change-Id: I6721cad9245e8722481c4c63023bb8b7193317ac
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/198836/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: * 'disk_info': a dict specifying disk configuration It contains the following 3 required fields bus (disk_bus), dev (disk_dev), type (device_type) and possibly these optional fields: ('format', 'boot_index')
deleted_lines: * 'disk_info': a tuple specifying disk configuration It contains the following 3 fields (disk bus, disk dev, device type) and possibly these optional fields: ('format',)

subject: libvirt: handle rescue flag first in blockinfo.get_disk_mapping
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-06 16:47:02.000000000', 'files': ['nova/virt/libvirt/blockinfo.py', 'nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_blockinfo.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/048eed3c6ce6fe859e735bb1d6509b90ecea2e72', 'message': "libvirt: handle rescue flag first in blockinfo.get_disk_mapping

If rescue is True, we don't need to get the flavor object from the
instance (which could lazy load it from the database) or figure out the
pre-assigned device names for the block_device_info list.

This just re-arranges the order of calls to be more efficient.

The related unit test is updated to show that get_disk_mapping works if
rescue=True and there is no Flavor object in the instance passed in.

Change-Id: I5ac7e4d3129c67db4efde0dda71c41b747952263
"}]
commit_message:
libvirt: handle rescue flag first in blockinfo.get_disk_mapping

If rescue is True, we don't need to get the flavor object from the
instance (which could lazy load it from the database) or figure out the
pre-assigned device names for the block_device_info list.

This just re-arranges the order of calls to be more efficient.

The related unit test is updated to show that get_disk_mapping works if
rescue=True and there is no Flavor object in the instance passed in.

Change-Id: I5ac7e4d3129c67db4efde0dda71c41b747952263

commit_message:
tweak graphviz formatting for readability

The "group" tag on nodes can be used to create vertical alignment, all
nodes in a group which are connected will end up in one column. This
makes reading the flow chart a bit easier.

Add a " " before the "no" edges otherwise they are left justified
completely to the vertical edge, and make it kind of gorpy to read.

Change-Id: Ife11e905ea6fdd97e1459fbbc001324eb946f9e4

commit_message:
Add security_group creation test without desc

If Neutron is used as a backend, security_group creation fails by not
passing description parameter. That is an internal error, and that
should be fixed later.
This patch is for reproducing the problem on the gate and sharing the
problem. After fixing, this test will be helpful for blocking the same
problem happens.

Change-Id: I880f1f56dc3e4293f6a278e344aa01b3c21314e2
Related-Bug: #1460875

commit_message:
Dell SC: Add support for ManageableVD

Added support for the ManageableVD volume driver class. This also
meant the driver changed from inheriting the volumedriver class to
inheriting the assorted *VD classes.

A few things about our ManageableVD support. We only allow management
of a volume if it is sized in multiples of 1GB. We only allow
management of volumes that are not currently mapped to a server on the
Storage Center. id-types of source-id (DeviceId on the Storage Center)
and source-name (Volume Name on the Storage Center) are supported.

Change-Id: Iecc93ce1654111e1292cfc1931d1eda4abd08595
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/31/199631/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: 2.0.0 - Switched to inheriting functional objects rather than volume driver. 2.1.0 - Added support for ManageableVD. VERSION = '2.1.0'

commit_message:
Corrected the "nova-quota-class" example in Operations Guide

I updated the "nova quota-class update" example in the "Managing Projects and
Users" chapter which incorrectly uses "instances" instead of "--instances".
The new example is "nova quota-class-update default --instances 15"

Change-Id: Id9bbc61fe70279190b853ff314333c84bfc1da25
Closes-Bug: #1479328
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/operations-guide refs/changes/56/207156/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>nova quota-class-update default --instances 15</userinput></screen>

commit_message:
virt: convert hardware module to use nova.objects.ImageMeta

Convert the APIs in the nova.virt.hardware module to expect to
receive an instance of nova.objects.ImageMeta instead of a
dict.

Update the virt drivers to convert the dict into an ImageMeta
module, as a stepping stone, until they to are converted to
use ImageMeta throughout.

Change-Id: Iac034d864cd0265759aaa7c8049fafa276763cc0

commit_message:
Allow overriding of the neutron endpoint URL in metadata agent

Allow operators to set the endpoint url for neutron in the config
overriding the url that comes from the keystone catalog.

Change-Id: I93f81ef1be2de1038d9a899b0c4becdb5a8e8775
DocImpact
Closes-Bug: #1466258

added_lines: from neutronclient.v2_0 import client endpoint_url = Noneclass TestNeutronClient(base.BaseTestCase): def test_client_params(self): fake_conf = FakeConf handler = agent.MetadataProxyHandler(fake_conf) with mock.patch.object( client.Client, "__init__", return_value=None) as mock_init: handler._get_neutron_client() expected_params = { 'username': 'neutron', 'region_name': 'region', 'ca_cert': None, 'tenant_name': 'tenant', 'insecure': False, 'token': None, 'endpoint_type': 'adminURL', 'auth_url': 'http://127.0.0.1', 'password': 'password', 'endpoint_url': None, 'auth_strategy': 'keystone', } mock_init.assert_called_once_with(**expected_params) def test_client_with_endpoint_url(self): fake_conf = FakeConf fake_conf.endpoint_url = 'http://127.0.0.0:8776' handler = agent.MetadataProxyHandler(fake_conf) with mock.patch.object( client.Client, "__init__", return_value=None) as mock_init: handler._get_neutron_client() expected_params = { 'username': 'neutron', 'region_name': 'region', 'ca_cert': None, 'tenant_name': 'tenant', 'insecure': False, 'token': None, 'auth_url': 'http://127.0.0.1', 'password': 'password', 'endpoint_url': 'http://127.0.0.0:8776', 'auth_strategy': 'keystone', } mock_init.assert_called_once_with(**expected_params)

commit_message:
Return the websocket response on invalid request

When a non-JSON object is passed to the websocket connection the error
is caught but wasn't returned, it is now.

Change-Id: I47338355a362272d2b4faee230947db06d644a87
Closes-Bug: #1477610

commit_message:
Add update tests for policies and rules

This patch adds tests for 'update' for both policies and rules. This
completes the CRUD tests and leaves the association/disassociation for
a later patch. Note that deleting a rule isn't tested explicitly
because of a bug with the rule delete logic on the server side. Once
that code is fixed, the test should be added.

to_dict() for policies should also convert any rules inside rule lists
to dicts too, otherwise API layer receives rule object __repr__ strings
instead of actual dicts. This patch introduces a fix to the existing
to_dict() code to properly support policies.

This patch also modifies the base infra to create policies and rules for
admins and not for tenant.

Partially-Implements: blueprint quantum-qos-api
Change-Id: I13870680d7756be9dd020135bc8e91d1c12f728d
Co-Authored-By: Ihar Hrachyshka <ihrachys@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/96/205796/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def update_qos_policy(self, policy_id, **kwargs): uri = '%s/qos/policies/%s' % (self.uri_prefix, policy_id) post_data = self.serialize({'policy': kwargs}) resp, body = self.put(uri, post_data) body = self.deserialize_single(body) self.expected_success(200, resp.status) return service_client.ResponseBody(resp, body) def update_bandwidth_limit_rule(self, policy_id, rule_id, **kwargs): post_data = {'bandwidth_limit_rule': kwargs} body = self.deserialize_single(body)
deleted_lines: def update_bandwidth_limit_rule(self, policy_id, rule_id, max_kbps, max_burst_kbps): post_data = { 'bandwidth_limit_rule': { 'max_kbps': max_kbps, 'max_burst_kbps': max_burst_kbps} }

commit_message:
Load the QoS notification driver from the configuration file

The agent based RPC notification driver for message queue is the default.

Added support for multiple notification drivers.

DocImpact

Partially-Implements: blueprint quantum-qos-api
Change-Id: I4108c3d111067d8217bc4112c05e1bde0125e0ef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/40/197840/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from neutron.i18n import _LI from neutron.services import provider_configuration as provconf from oslo_config import cfgfrom oslo_utils import importutilsQOS_DRIVER = 'qos_backend_driver' QOS_PLUGIN_OPTS = [ cfg.StrOpt('qos_backend_driver', default='neutron.services.qos.drivers.rpc.msq_qos.RPCQoSDriver', help=_('Driver to use to send the cheange notification ')), ] cfg.CONF.register_opts(QOS_PLUGIN_OPTS) self.driver = self._load_driver_instance() def _load_driver_instance(self): """Returns an instance of the configured QoS driver :returns: An instance of Driver for the QoS notification """ if not cfg.CONF.qos_backend_driver: raise SystemExit(_('An QoS driver must be specified')) qos_driver_name = provconf.get_provider_driver_class( cfg.CONF.qos_backend_driver, QOS_DRIVER) LOG.info(_LI("Loading QoS driver %s"), qos_driver_name) driver_class = importutils.import_object( qos_driver_name) return driver_class
deleted_lines: from neutron.services.qos.drivers.rpc import msq_qos #TODO(QoS)(gampel) add load module from config file self.driver = msq_qos.RPCQoSDriver()

commit_message:
Glance index visibility should only be for v1

The fix for bug 1478294 caused a regression in indexing, because the image
object coming in does not have a pop function on it, causing images to not
be indexed at all.

This changes this to only do visibility "fixing" on notifications.

Change-Id: I62e6df2458d802aa8c776e8c87fe49a01e4b71f3
Closes-Bug: #1479150
Co-Authored-By: Lakshmi N Sampath <lakshmi.sampath@hp.com>

commit_message:
Add pluggable backend driver for QoS Service notification

Added a reference driver for the agent based solutions
RPC sending the messages over the message queue

Partially-Implements: blueprint quantum-qos-api
Change-Id: I725c876739ff85b4db8fb053de0362ce367ae78c

added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2015 OpenStack Foundation. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from neutron import manager from neutron.api.rpc.callbacks import events from neutron.api.rpc.callbacks import registry as rpc_registry from neutron.api.rpc.callbacks import resources from neutron.i18n import _LW from neutron.plugins.common import constants from neutron.services.qos.drivers import qos_base from oslo_log import log as logging LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) def _get_qos_policy_cb_stub(resource, policy_id, **kwargs): """Hardcoded stub for testing until we get the db working.""" qos_policy = { "tenant_id": "8d4c70a21fed4aeba121a1a429ba0d04", "id": "46ebaec0-0570-43ac-82f6-60d2b03168c4", "name": "10Mbit", "description": "This policy limits the ports to 10Mbit max.", "shared": False, "rules": [{ "id": "5f126d84-551a-4dcf-bb01-0e9c0df0c793", "max_kbps": "10000", "max_burst_kbps": "0", "type": "bandwidth_limit" }] } return qos_policy def _get_qos_policy_cb(resource, policy_id, **kwargs): qos_plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( constants.QOS) context = kwargs.get('context') if context is None: LOG.warning(_LW( 'Received %(resource)s %(policy_id)s without context'), {'resource': resource, 'policy_id': policy_id} ) return qos_policy = qos_plugin.get_qos_policy(context, policy_id) return qos_policy #TODO(QoS): remove this stub when db is ready def _get_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule_cb_stub(resource, rule_id, **kwargs): """Hardcoded for testing until we get the db working.""" bandwidth_limit = { "id": "5f126d84-551a-4dcf-bb01-0e9c0df0c793", "qos_policy_id": "46ebaec0-0570-43ac-82f6-60d2b03168c4", "max_kbps": "10000", "max_burst_kbps": "0", } return bandwidth_limit #TODO(QoS): remove this stub when db is ready def _get_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule_cb(resource, rule_id, **kwargs): qos_plugin = manager.NeutronManager.get_service_plugins().get( constants.QOS) context = kwargs.get('context') if context is None: LOG.warning(_LW( 'Received %(resource)s %(rule_id,)s without context '), {'resource': resource, 'rule_id,': rule_id} ) return bandwidth_limit = qos_plugin.get_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule( context, rule_id) return bandwidth_limit class RPCQoSDriver(qos_base.QoSDriverBase): """RPC driver for QoS As A Service.""" def __init__(self): LOG.debug("Initializing rpc msq driver") self.register_resource_providers() def create_policy(self, policy): LOG.debug("Create policy for %s", policy['id']) #No need to update agents on create pass def update_policy(self, policy): rpc_registry.notify(resources.QOS_POLICY, events.UPDATED, policy) def delete_policy(self, policy): rpc_registry.notify(resources.QOS_POLICY, events.DELETE, policy) def register_resource_providers(self): rpc_registry.register_provider( _get_qos_bandwidth_limit_rule_cb_stub, resources.QOS_RULE) rpc_registry.register_provider( _get_qos_policy_cb_stub, resources.QOS_POLICY)

commit_message:
Add HTTP Async Batch call

In order to make multiple async calls in javascript, we need to nest them.
This makes the code unreadable at some point. There is a better way to
batch multiple async calls using defer and promises. This patch provides a
way to batch async calls and handle it once ALL async calls are complete.

Change-Id: I28beb4fd8efdd5ea85cadd639d6f9daf78de07a4
Closes-Bug: #1479162

commit_message:
Adding wizard modal service

The way angular-bootstrap modal work is a bit strange.
This is a problem because it requires us to define controller A for open.
And it also forces controller B to define close and dismiss.
The result is a bunch of controllers just to open a modal dialog.

This service aims to simplify that by centralizing open, close, and dismiss.
It also provides some default options that you must override via init.

Link to documentation:
https://angular-ui.github.io/bootstrap/#/modal

Change-Id: Ie5b1344794a301e9d1585c3dece2690f1281e4a9
Partially-Implements: blueprint angularize-identity-tables
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/16/205716/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: /** * Copyright 2015 IBM Corp. * * Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may * not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain * a copy of the License at * * http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 * * Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software * distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT * WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations * under the License. */ (function() { 'use strict'; /** * @ngDoc hz.framework.wizard.modal.service * @ngFactory * * @Description * The way angular-bootstrap modal work is a bit strange. * You have $modal in controller A which you can use to open to controller B. * You have $modalInstance in controller B spawn, which you can use to close or dismiss. * Upon closing, you can choose to pass information back to controller A. * The dismiss method does nothing. * * This is a problem because it requires us to define controller A for open. * And it also forces controller B to define close and dismiss. * The result is a bunch of controllers just to open a modal dialog. * * This service aims to simplify that by centralizing open, close, and dismiss. * It also provides some default options that you must override via init. * The override MUST contain a controller. * * @Example * * app.controller('tableController', function(modalService){ * modalService.init({ controller: 'wizardController' }).open(); * }); * * app.controller('wizardController', function($scope, $modalInstance, modalService){ * $scope.close = modalService.close($modalInstance); * $scope.cancel = modalService.cancel($modalInstance); * $scope.submit = function(){....}; * $scope.workflow = workflow({ * title: 'Title', * steps: [...] * }); * }); * */ angular .module('horizon.framework.widgets.modal') .factory('horizon.framework.widgets.modal.wizard-modal.service', modalService); modalService.$inject = ['$modal']; function modalService($modal) { var service = { open: open, close: close, cancel: cancel, init: init }; return service; /////////////////////////////// function init(options) { service.options = angular.extend(options, { controllerAs: 'ctrl', template: '<wizard></wizard>', backdrop: 'static', windowClass: 'modal-dialog-wizard', resolve: { modalService: self } }); return service; } function self() { return service; } function open() { $modal.open(service.options); } function close($modalInstance) { return function() { $modalInstance.close(); }; } function cancel($modalInstance) { return function() { $modalInstance.dismiss('cancel'); }; } } })();

commit_message:
Port StorwizeSVCDriver to use ABCMeta driver model

Use new ABCMeta driver model for StorwizeSVCDriver driver.
Also add empty function unmanage for ManageableVD.

Partially-implements: blueprint abc-driver-update

Change-Id: Ib92342186908a4e148fcb341b38de012047e8c22

subject: Adding methods to network driver to get more info
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-23 22:08:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/75d782bce492e9966dd53ab11c084ec490598e1c', 'message': "Adding methods to network driver to get more info

The network driver needs the ability to retrieve specific information about
subnets and ports and pass that information to other components.  Having info
about the subnet gives us cidr and gateway data that is valuable when setting
up the amphora's routes for the separation of tenant data and management data.
Because of this need, methods to retrieve network, subnet, and port details
has been added.

This also adds a another data model AmphoraNetworkConfig that contains subnet
and port information for the vip, vrrp, and ha networks on an amphora.  A
network task has been added that builds this data structure by calling the new
methods added to the network driver.

Change-Id: Ica912337c7d52659a9733096878664f734f27b00

commit_message:
Adding methods to network driver to get more info

The network driver needs the ability to retrieve specific information about
subnets and ports and pass that information to other components.  Having info
about the subnet gives us cidr and gateway data that is valuable when setting
up the amphora's routes for the separation of tenant data and management data.
Because of this need, methods to retrieve network, subnet, and port details
has been added.

This also adds a another data model AmphoraNetworkConfig that contains subnet
and port information for the vip, vrrp, and ha networks on an amphora.  A
network task has been added that builds this data structure by calling the new
methods added to the network driver.

Change-Id: Ica912337c7d52659a9733096878664f734f27b00

commit_message:
Adopt openstack-config for eslint

Since openstack-config for eslint is now published on npm we should use
it as basis for our linting rules. It is actually stricter, than our
current semi-default config as it enables some of the previously
unchecked rules.

Partially implements: blueprint add-js-lint-jobs

Change-Id: I0cb8247167a44f30a657693442f99a87f116350a

commit_message:
Add subnet extra routes to lbaas namespace

This change adds VIP subnet's extra routes to
lbaas namespace so that load balancers can reach
the same networks as their instance do.

Change-Id: I217f65376d41818709a97b902567668a4af77a4c
Closes-Bug:1379016

commit_message:
Ensure database options registered for tests

DeprecatedTestCase and DeprecatedOverrideTestCase use options in the
database section, but these options won't be registered unless
keystone.common.sql.initialize() is called.

This caused the python34 tests to fail with

 oslo_config.cfg.NoSuchOptError: no such option: database

bp python3

Closes-Bug: 1474491
Change-Id: Ic6376142e5e14f1b25cc203c5b37751dc0a25981

commit_message:
add -n --name flag to worlddump

We're worlddumping at success points in grenade, and it would be much
handier to explain when that happens via a symbolic name in the
filename. Add a --name option to worlddump to allow it.

Change-Id: I644200fe08e404dc7ca2006478ae4e11ca020672

commit_message:
(DO NOT MERGE/WIP/POC) OVSFirewallDriver

I have updated the driver for Kilo, and I intend to update
it for connection tracking.

This is just a test for backup purposes.

Co-Authored-By: Amir Sadoughi < ....>

commit_message:
Define IptablesNatDriver stateful nat driver

This change defines IptablesNatDriver: driver to manage iptables-based
(stateful) nat and removes current implementation from router_info
module[1].

This change is an enabler to stateless/stateful nats, follow-up changes
will define tc-based (stateless) nat and allow to choose what
implementation to use.

[1] neutron.agent.l3.router_info

Partially-Implements: blueprint stateless-floatingips
Change-Id: Ie1f00d7ead08bb33e76e7f4403a1c30cd72fb664
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/68/181168/12 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _test_l3_init_ip_cleaner(self, ip_cleaner): bc.init_l3('tap0', ['10.0.0.1/24'], namespace=ns, ip_cleaner=ip_cleaner) if ip_cleaner: ip_cleaner.assert_called_once_with(namespace=ns, ip='10.0.0.3/32') def test_l3_init_with_ip_cleaner(self): self._test_l3_init_ip_cleaner(mock.Mock()) def test_l3_init_without_ip_cleaner(self): self._test_l3_init_ip_cleaner(None)
deleted_lines: def _test_l3_init_clean_connections(self, clean_connections): with mock.patch.object(bc, 'delete_conntrack_state') as delete: bc.init_l3('tap0', ['10.0.0.1/24'], namespace=ns, clean_connections=clean_connections) if clean_connections: delete.assert_called_once_with( namespace=ns, ip='10.0.0.3/32') else: self.assertFalse(delete.called) def test_l3_init_with_clean_connections(self): self._test_l3_init_clean_connections(True) def test_l3_init_without_clean_connections(self): self._test_l3_init_clean_connections(False)

subject: Check router is def gw before adding floating IP
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-26 07:17:54.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/46fabbceb202f9ec35b3eb969d4e24a8162730c9', 'message': "Check router is def gw before adding floating IP

If there are multiple routers that have ports on the appropriate private
net and are gateways, the first one found will be selected for a
floating-ip allocation.  Sometimes, that's not the router that is the
default gateway for instances, this change puts an additional check in
place.

Change-Id: Iaeedeb4e76e03801ad0f810d55bcfd2be174a381
Related-Bug: 1458471
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-26 07:20:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/393bfb910fad56ee5c31e14d33d89ef66a2ddd3a', 'message': "Check router is def gw before adding floating IP

If there are multiple routers that have ports on the appropriate private
net and are gateways, the first one found will be selected for a
floating-ip allocation.  Sometimes, that's not the router that is the
default gateway for instances, this change puts an additional check in
place.

Change-Id: Iaeedeb4e76e03801ad0f810d55bcfd2be174a381
Related-Bug: 1458471
"}, {'number': 3, 'created': '2015-05-26 08:32:18.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/fa8f0f4e0f02fa78eba7c6223797cf7031e6da0b', 'message': "Check router is def gw before adding floating IP

If there are multiple routers that have ports on the appropriate private
net and are gateways, the first one found will be selected for a
floating-ip allocation.  Sometimes, that's not the router that is the
default gateway for instances, this change puts an additional check in
place.

commit_message:
Check router is def gw before adding floating IP

If there are multiple routers that have ports on the appropriate private
net and are gateways, the first one found will be selected for a
floating-ip allocation.  Sometimes, that's not the router that is the
default gateway for instances, this change puts an additional check in
place.

Change-Id: Iaeedeb4e76e03801ad0f810d55bcfd2be174a381
Closes-Bug: 1458471

revisions:

Change-Id: I0b715f6632845a1ed98e23af1a99277c8fb345dc

commit_message:
Support creating GRE tunnel between routers

Change-Id: I0b715f6632845a1ed98e23af1a99277c8fb345dc
Blueprint: gre-tunnel-between-routers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/69/152769/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Support creating GRE tunnel between routers =========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/gre-tunnel-between-routers Support creating GRE tunnel between routers, so we can connect different OpenStack clouds, and even connect OpenStack cloud with hardware devices, to enable l3 communication. Problem Description =================== When trying to connect different OpenStack clouds, and even connect OpenStack cloud with hardware devices for l3 communication, creating GRE tunnel between routers has some advantages compared with the current VPNaaS implementation. Firstly, one can only assigns one subnet to an ipsec site connection. So if we have more than one subnets attached to a router, and want to connect these subnets with other subnets attached to another router, we need to create more than one ipsec site connections. While using GRE tunnel, we can just create one tunnel between two routers, and then configure the routes to enable connections between different subnets. Secondly, in the case of connecting OpenStack cloud with hardware devices, GRE tunnel has better hardware devices support, while not much router devices have native VPN support. We need to deploy extra VPN devices if we use VPNaaS. Proposed Change =============== For ease of operation, new API to explicitly create GRE tunnel between routers is not introduced, instead, a new configuration for neutron l3 agent called 'l3gw_extern_net_ip_range' is added. Users can set 'l3gw_extern_net_ip_range' to a range of ip address. Each time an extra route is added to a router, l3 agent will check if the nexthop is in the configured range of ip address. If so, a tunnel interface will be created in the router namespace with nexthop as the remote ip, and ip address of gateway port as the local ip. The peer router should have a corresponding extra route to build the GRE connection. The graph below shows the network topology. asciiflow:: +-----------------------+ | GRE tunnel | | | 100.64.2.5| 100.64.1.5| +-----+-----+ +-----+-----+ |Destination| |Destination| |192.168.1.7| |192.168.2.8| |nexthop | |nexthop | |100.64.1.5 | |100.64.2.5 | | | | | | Router1 | | Router2 | | | | | +-----+-----+ +-----+-----+ | | +----++-----+ +----++-----+ | vm1 | | vm2 | |192.168.2.8| |192.168.1.7| +-----------+ +-----------+ Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API Impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- None Notifications Impact -------------------- None Other End User Impact --------------------- * Users should properly configure 'l3gw_extern_net_ip_range' to cover ip ranges of external networks in different OpenStack clouds. * Users should properly configure extra routes to enable l3 communication between different OpenStack clouds. Performance Impact ------------------ As a light weight encapsulation protocol, GRE tunnel has better performance than VPN connection. IPv6 Impact ----------- IPv6 subnet not supported. Other Deployer Impact --------------------- None Developer Impact ---------------- None Community Impact ---------------- None Alternatives ------------ VPN can also be used to connect OpenStack clouds, but as discussed in 'Problem Description' section, it has some limitations. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: caizhiyuan1@huawei.com Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- * Remove nexthop restriction, see 'Dependencies' section. * Add 'l3gw_extern_net_ip_range' configuration to l3 agent. * Add GRE tunnel operation to l3 agent. Dependencies ============ Depend on: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/route-nexthop-not-in-router-subnet This feature is utilized to connect different OpenStack clouds, who may be attached to different external networks. Thus the nexthop pointing to the peer OpenStack cloud may be not in the current OpenStack cloud's external network. Currently extra route with such nexthop can not be added to a router because neutron will check if the nexthop is in one of the router's attaching subnets and raise BadRequest error if not. The blueprint cited above proposes to remove this restriction. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- N/A Functional Tests ---------------- * Test if GRE tunnel is correctly setup when extra route is added. * Test if GRE tunnel is correctly removed when extra route is removed. API Tests --------- N/A Documentation Impact ==================== User Documentation ------------------ * Introduce new configuration 'l3gw_extern_net_ip_range'. * Introduce behaviour of l3 agent when route with nexthop in 'l3gw_extern_net_ip_range' is added. Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== Depend on this blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/route-nexthop-not-in-router-subnet

commit_message:
Support port metering

Though now we have metering agent based on metering label, but
there are still some scenarios it can't meet.  Such as for the
VMs directly plugged on provider network or when the traffic
doesn't go through a virtual router. This patch will add the
support for port metering to cover those cases.

blueprint port-metering

Co-Authored-By: Sylvain Afchain(sylvain.afchain@enovance.com)

Change-Id: I20658a07753ea5efa4e95cf2fa3ac7a0eb3818c5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/41/192941/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (C) 2013 eNovance SAS <licensing@enovance.com> # # Author: Sylvain Afchain <sylvain.afchain@enovance.com> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import re from neutron.agent.common import ovs_lib from neutron.agent.port_metering.drivers import abstract_driver from neutron.common import log class OvsPortMeteringDriver(abstract_driver.PortMeteringAbstractDriver): @log.log def get_ports_counters(self, ports): import pdb pdb.set_trace() port_name_id_map = dict((port['port_name'], port['port_id']) for port in ports) pdb.set_trace() result = ovs_lib.BaseOVS().run_dpctl(['-s', 'show']) ports_counters = {} curr_port_id = None for line in result.splitlines(): if 'port ' in line: port_infos = line.strip().split() port_name = port_infos[2] if port_name in port_name_id_map: curr_port_id = port_name_id_map[port_name] else: curr_port_id = None continue match = re.match(r".*RX\sbytes:(\d+).*TX\sbytes:(\d+).*", line) if curr_port_id and match: port_counter = ports_counters.get(curr_port_id, {}) port_counter['bytes_rx'] = int(match.group(1)) port_counter['bytes_tx'] = int(match.group(2)) ports_counters[curr_port_id] = port_counter continue match = re.match(r".*([RT]X)\spackets:(\d+).*", line) if curr_port_id and match: key = 'packets_rx' if match.group(1) == 'TX': key = 'packets_tx' port_counter = ports_counters.get(curr_port_id, {}) port_counter[key] = int(match.group(2)) ports_counters[curr_port_id] = port_counter return ports_counters

commit_message:
Add ovs to requirements.txt

The Python ovs library has been added to PyPI, so we can add it to
requirements.txt now and remove the special package-installation
done in configure_for_func_testing.sh.

Signed-off-by: Terry Wilson <twilson@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Vmware NSXv: Allow admin to control security-groups rule logging

NSXv distributed firewall expose api to control rule logging,
as for the moment, admin user can use this feature only from inside of
the distributed firewall.
This patch make use of this api to provide the cloud admin with three ways
to control security-group logging:

    - log whenever security-group rule is matched
    - log when a packet doesn't match any security-group rule
    - log whenever security-group rule is matched for selected
      security-groups

Closes-Bug: #1449901
Change-Id: Id9b8376e3a30201434679a75613fb95aabf09b34

commit_message:
WIP - Python neutron client API operation
Added description of how to use the various neutron client API operation from python code.
Provided the description of the operation and the parameters used by each operation.

Change-Id: I16129de66cc18594871605e6d6b11488713debfc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient refs/changes/80/191180/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Python Client API Operations ============================ List network:: list_networks(retrieve_all=True, \**kwargs) Returns a list of networks that tenant has access to. Parameters: **retrieve_all** (optional) Show network:: show_network(network,\**kwargs) Returns data about the network specified Parameter : **network** - the ID of the network to be shown Create network:: body = {"network": {"name" : "my_network"} } create_network(body=body) Creates a new neutron network with the body specified Parameter: **body** – the name and and admin_state_up for the network Update network:: body = {"network": {"name" : "updated_name"} } update_network(network, body=body) Updates some attributes of the network object Parameter : **network** - the ID of the network that is to be updated **body** - specify the updated information here Delete network:: delete_network(network) Remove the neutron network and all its associated subnets Parameter : **network** - the ID of the network to be deleted List subnets:: list_subnets(retrieve_all=True, \**kwargs) Returns a list of subnet objects that tenant has access to Parameters: **retrieve_all** (optional) Show subnet:: show_subnet(subnet, \**kwargs) Returns data about the subnet specified Parameter : **subnet** - the ID of the subnet to be shown Create subnet:: body = { "subnet": { "network_id": "ed2e3c10-2e43-4297-9006-2863a2d1abbc", "ip_version": 4, "cidr": "10.0.3.0/24", "allocation_pools": [{"start": "10.0.3.20", "end": "10.0.3.150"}] } } create_subnet(body=body) Creates a new subnet on a specific network. Network_id is mandantory in the body Parameter: **body** – parameters to create a new subnet Delete subnet:: delete_subnet(subnet) Remove the specified subnets Parameter : **subnet** - the ID of the subnet to be deleted

commit_message:
Add additional time for starting l3 agents during scheduling

If l3 agent get killed and there are a lot of resources assigned
on it, the agent on which this resources are rescheduling can be
marked as dead for neutron-server because state reports are not
received in agent_down_time*2.

This is similar issue which was previously found for DHCP agent.

Co-Authored-By: Eugene Nikanorov <enikanorov@mirantis.com>

Closes-bug: #1440761

Change-Id: Id00cbeafe0d830ee9386fee253fc49b96e6a7611
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/92/171592/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import datetimefrom oslo_utils import timeutils def _filter_bindings(self, context, bindings): # to save few db calls: store already checked agents in dict # id -> is_agent_starting_up checked_agents = {} for binding in bindings: agent_id = binding.l3_agent['id'] if agent_id not in checked_agents: if self.agent_starting_up(context, binding.l3_agent): # When agent starts and it has many networks to process # it may fail to send state reports in defined interval. # The server will consider it dead and try to remove # networks from it. checked_agents[agent_id] = True LOG.debug("Agent %s is starting up, skipping", agent_id) else: checked_agents[agent_id] = False if not checked_agents[agent_id]: yield binding def agent_starting_up(self, context, agent): """Check if agent was just started. Method returns True if agent is in its 'starting up' period. Return value depends on amount of networks assigned to the agent. It doesn't look at latest heartbeat timestamp as it is assumed that this method is called for agents that are considered dead. """ agent_dead_limit = datetime.timedelta( seconds=self.agent_dead_limit_seconds()) router_count = context.session.query(RouterL3AgentBinding).filter_by( l3_agent_id=agent['id']).count() additional_time = datetime.timedelta(milliseconds=50 * router_count) LOG.debug("Checking if agent starts up and giving it additional %s", additional_time) LOG.info("Addional time %s" % additional_time) agent_expected_up = (agent['started_at'] + agent_dead_limit + additional_time) LOG.info("agent_expected_up %s" % agent_expected_up) return agent_expected_up > timeutils.utcnow() down_bindings = self._filter_bindings(context,

commit_message:
allow set ip info in router-gateway-set command

e.g.
neutron router-gateway-set router-id ext-network-id
--subnet subnet --address xx.xx.yy.x

Co-Authored-By: gongysh <gong.yongsheng@99cloud.net>
Change-Id: I628bb8df22065e9e05012f519523ad0084d26f39
Closes-Bug: #1411115

commit_message:
Add Nuage plugin configuration parameters.

The Nuage plugin can handle floating ip rate limiting. This commit adds
two new parameters to the plugin config file, related to the floating ip
rate limiting of Nuage.

Change-Id: Ib75e7a12e185f63fb8a875d404e3df379ca7aebe
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/22/187922/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Use stevedore to load nat driver

This change defines the "nat_driver" option used to load (using
stevedore) nat driver implementation. One driver implementation is
available: the "stateful" driver, the current implementation.

This change is an enabler to stateless/stateful nats, follow-up
changes will define tc-based (stateless) nat driver.

Partially-Implements: blueprint stateless-floatingips

Change-Id: I005ba893ef556f98619045c6f36dc7284b5df125
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/71/181471/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: neutron.agent.l3.nat_drivers = stateful = neutron.agent.l3.nat:IptablesNatDriver

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-27 12:35:52.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/tests/unit/plugins/openvswitch/agent/test_ovs_neutron_agent.py', 'neutron/plugins/openvswitch/agent/ovs_neutron_agent.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/90783011bc70578b71c1c7924a1fd7786c5f1469', 'message': "Handle KeyError for local_vlan_map in port_bound

OVS-agent's network_delete calls reclaim_local_vlan, which removes
the corresponding entry from local_vlan_map. If it happens at a wrong
moment, main thread can end up with raising KeyError in port_bound.

Change-Id: I411c92386e48dbd6435d5daa4217e386ce463ed0
Closes-Bug: #1455338
"}]
commit_message:
Handle KeyError for local_vlan_map in port_bound

OVS-agent's network_delete calls reclaim_local_vlan, which removes
the corresponding entry from local_vlan_map. If it happens at a wrong
moment, main thread can end up with raising KeyError in port_bound.

Change-Id: I411c92386e48dbd6435d5daa4217e386ce463ed0
Closes-Bug: #1455338
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/57/185957/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: lvm = self.local_vlan_map[net_uuid] except KeyError: LOG.debug("Network %s has been deleted concurrently and " "its local vlan was reclaimed", net_uuid) return

subject: br-tun lost ports/flows if openvswitch restart
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-02-27 10:10:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/dc5723fd9cec5aa49ff19a6cb083c0f5c3f00d0b', 'message': 'br-tun lost ports/flows if openvswitch restart

Description:
When openvswitch restarts, neutron_ovs_agent will reset the br-tun bridge,
which removes all tunnel ports/flows.

Each neutron_ovs_agent could maintain all l2 population fdb entries locally and
make every fdb add/remove/update operations thread-safe to improve the
reliability.

Implementation:
If l2 population is enabled, it maintains all l2 population fdb entries locally
and recreates ports/flows.

Closes-Bug: #1332450

Change-Id: Ie7dc547e41ac33b2ba830a0c3a3524f2bf67fcb8
Co-Authored-By: Romil Gupta <romilg@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Neethi Shashidhar <neethi209@gmail.com>

commit_message:
br-tun lost ports/flows if openvswitch restart

Description:
When openvswitch restarts, neutron_ovs_agent will reset the br-tun bridge,
which removes all tunnel ports/flows.

Each neutron_ovs_agent could maintain all l2 population fdb entries locally and
make every fdb add/remove/update operations thread-safe to improve the
reliability.

Implementation:
If l2 population is enabled, it maintains all l2 population fdb entries locally
and recreates ports/flows.

Closes-Bug: #1332450

Co-Authored-By: Romil Gupta <romilg@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Neethi Shashidhar <neethi209@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ie7dc547e41ac33b2ba830a0c3a3524f2bf67fcb8

added_lines: from oslo_concurrency import lockutils self.l2_pop_fdb_cache = {} @lockutils.synchronized('fdb', 'ovs-agent') self._do_fdb_add(context, fdb_entries) def _do_fdb_add(self, context, fdb_entries): for lvm, agent_ports, cur_agent_ports in self.get_agent_ports_add( fdb_entries, self.local_vlan_map): self.fdb_add_tun(context, self.tun_br, lvm, agent_ports, self._tunnel_port_lookup, cur_agent_ports) agent_ports, self._tunnel_port_lookup, cur_agent_ports) @lockutils.synchronized('fdb', 'ovs-agent') self._do_fdb_remove(context, fdb_entries) def _do_fdb_remove(self, context, fdb_entries): for lvm, agent_ports, cur_agent_ports in self.get_agent_ports_remove( fdb_entries, self.local_vlan_map): self._tunnel_port_lookup, cur_agent_ports) agent_ports, self._tunnel_port_lookup, cur_agent_ports) @lockutils.synchronized('fdb', 'ovs-agent') def _refresh_l2_pop_fdb_entries(self): for tunnel_type in self.tunnel_types: self.tun_br_ofports[tunnel_type].clear() # TODO(Amank): add a new rpc to retrieve fdb entries # from server will be better old_fdb_entries = self.l2_pop_fdb_cache self.l2_pop_fdb_cache = {} self._do_fdb_add(None, old_fdb_entries) if self.l2_pop: self._refresh_l2_pop_fdb_entries()
deleted_lines: for lvm, agent_ports in self.get_agent_ports(fdb_entries, self.local_vlan_map): self.fdb_add_tun(context, deferred_br, lvm, agent_ports, self._tunnel_port_lookup) agent_ports, self._tunnel_port_lookup) for lvm, agent_ports in self.get_agent_ports(fdb_entries, self.local_vlan_map): self._tunnel_port_lookup) agent_ports, self._tunnel_port_lookup)

subject: Introduce RPC tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-03-10 00:35:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/dca8508e7cb329363159001f5f0ca880139e701a', 'message': "Introduce RPC tests

The only place we test the interaction between agents and the controller
is in Tempest. These are however 'heavy' tests and are very high level.
There are features that aren't tested in Tempest (Due to no multi node testing
or for other reasons) that have coverage for each individual component but
not for how they interact. In-tree full-stack testing will mitigate this,
but like Tempest, it is too high level as basic RPC interaction can be tested
at a lower level.

The idea is to use the fake Oslo messaging driver (Which is already being
used every where) but to take care not to  mock out critical bits. The fake
driver simply passes messages around in-process without the use of an external
messaging service. The server RPC handlers are already being tested,
so there's no need to test them again. The Oslo messaging driver is not under
test either. So what is being tested? These sort of RPC tests just call an RPC
method from a client, without mocking anything. If the RPC method is expected
to return something, that should be asserted as well.

These tests can catch regressions such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1414812

Future work:
* Mock heavy unit tests that assert that True == True may now be replaced.
* Testing 'rolling upgrades' by simulating a client of a lower or higher version,
  in and outside of RPC namespaces.
  re: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2015-March/058280.html

These tests may be run (On your laptop) with:
tox -e functional neutron.tests.functional.api.rpc

Change-Id: I7b15f15f69acf2fc4e01e754f6490cdbb37b453e

commit_message:
Introduce RPC tests

The only place we test the interaction between agents and the controller
is in Tempest. These are however 'heavy' tests and are very high level.
There are features that aren't tested in Tempest (Due to no multi node testing
or for other reasons) that have coverage for each individual component but
not for how they interact. In-tree full-stack testing will mitigate this,
but like Tempest, it is too high level as basic RPC interaction can be tested
at a lower level.

The idea is to use the fake Oslo messaging driver (Which is already being
used every where) but to take care not to  mock out critical bits. The fake
driver simply passes messages around in-process without the use of an external
messaging service. The server RPC handlers are already being tested,
so there's no need to test them again. The Oslo messaging driver is not under
test either. So what is being tested? These sort of RPC tests just call an RPC
method from a client, without mocking anything. If the RPC method is expected
to return something, that should be asserted as well.

These tests can catch regressions such as:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1414812

Future work in dependent patches:
* Complete coverage for all RPC methods.
* Mock heavy unit tests that assert that True == True may now be replaced.
* Rolling upgrades cannot be tested via this framework, but via something
  similar to grenade, which Nova always runs with Nova network. I hope
  to look into running it with Neutron as well.

These tests may be run (On your laptop) with:
tox -e functional neutron.tests.functional.api.rpc

This patch includes RPC tests for the agent report_state and
L3 agent methods just so we can be sure the RPC testing framework
provides sufficient functionality for different RPC endpoints.

Change-Id: I7b15f15f69acf2fc4e01e754f6490cdbb37b453e

commit_message:
Identify tenant_id's existence for admin user

When creating networking resource, admin user can override
tenant_id attribute arbitrarily, and we should add a check
to make sure the tenant_id is exist. This is not a common issue,
but may be exist in real environment, for example, admin user
may use an expired tenant_id, which has been deleted, to create
networking resources. To avoid requesting keystone too frequently,
this patch follows metadata agent's cache mechnism, and is
implemented by using @utils.cache_method_results decorator.

Closes-bug: #1200585

Change-Id: If341778e3fe986a3c4f9e97c634d701794dd6727
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/64/186264/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfg from keystoneclient.v2_0 import client as keyclient keystone_conf = cfg.CONF.keystone_authtoken client = keyclient.Client(token = context.auth_token, endpoint = keystone_conf.auth_uri) # check if the tenant_id is exist, if not, raise an exception try: client.tenants.get(tenant_id) except: raise n_exc.TenantNotFound(tenant_id=tenant_id)

subject: Neutron pydevd debugger support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-10-07 12:35:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/f6ef7c7b68b58a0a91bfc45846226c88765fd52d', 'message': 'Adding a means for the Neutron process to connect back to a pydevd debugger.

That patch allows a developer to remotely run a pydev debugger and having the
Neutron process connect backto it.

The implementation is similar to the one found in the Keystone or glance
project.

Three configuration options have been added:

    pydev-debug-host <host>. Default is None
    pydev-debug-port <port>. Default is None
    standard-threads (bool). Default is False

The behavior is enabled if `pydev-debug-host` *and* `pydev-debug-port` are not
 None.

If the behavior is enabled, an os.environ variable will be set to indicate
that the thread must not get monkey patched:
(http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-August/000794.html).
Then, the pydev connection will be performed by the server right when starting
after reading the configuration.

Minor modifications were required to deal with the multiple calls to the
eventlet monkey patcher in multiple places throughout the Neutron code: a new
method in common.utils has been defined performing the actual patch and
checking if whether or not standard threads are in use to discard thread patch
calls. Calls to eventlet monkey patcher have been changed to call the new
method in common.utils throughout the Neutrong code.

`standard-threads` option can be enabled independently of the pydev debug
options using the configuration options or by simply setting up an
environment variable called `STANDARD_THREADS`.

If the pydev connection fails to be established with the remote debugger an
exception is raised.
