'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-10-08 02:47:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/596c83b110812d64edba541520733b97b82c75aa', 'message': 'Neutron pydevd debugger support.

That patch allows a developer to remotely run a pydev debugger and having the
Neutron process connect back to it.

The implementation is similar to the one found in the Keystone or glance
project.

Four configuration options have been added:

    pydev-debug-host <host>. Default is None
    pydev-debug-port <port>. Default is None
    standard-threads (bool): Do not monkey-patch threading system modules.
    no-standard-threads (bool): inverse of --standard-threads

The behavior is enabled if `pydev-debug-host` *and* `pydev-debug-port` are
both not None.

Example:

1. neutron connecting back to pydevd using standard threads

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 22222

2. neutron connection back to pydevd using patched threads

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 22222 --no-standard-threads

If the behavior is enabled, an os.environ variable will be set to indicate
that the thread must not get monkey patched:
(http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-August/000794.html).
Then, the pydev connection will be performed by the server right when starting
after reading the configuration.

Minor modifications were required to deal with the multiple calls to the
eventlet monkey patcher in multiple places throughout the Neutron code: a new
method in common.utils has been defined performing the actual patch and
checking if whether or not standard threads are in use to discard thread patch
calls. Calls to eventlet monkey patcher have been changed to call the new
method in common.utils throughout the Neutrong code.

`standard-threads` option can be enabled independently of the pydev debug
options using the configuration options or by simply setting up an
environment variable called `STANDARD_THREADS`.

If the pydev connection fails to be established with the remote debugger an
exception is raised.

This patch will allow remote debugging as well as more seamless debugging
environments with IDEs not compatible with patched threads.

Change-Id: Idd4485b405cf0707781aa1250819a2140ee74550

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 12345 --no-standard-threads

If the behavior is enabled, an os.environ variable will be set to indicate
that the thread must not get monkey patched:
(http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-August/000794.html).
Then, the pydev connection will be performed by the server right when starting
after reading the configuration.

Minor modifications were required to deal with the multiple calls to the
eventlet monkey patcher in multiple places throughout the Neutron code: a new
module in common has been defined performing the actual patch and
checking if whether or not standard threads are in use to discard thread patch
calls. Calls to eventlet monkey patcher have been changed to leverage this new
module throughout the Neutron code.

`standard-threads` option can be enabled independently of the pydev debug
options using the configuration options or by simply setting up an
environment variable called `STANDARD_THREADS`.

If the pydev connection fails to be established with the remote debugger an
exception is raised.

This patch will allow remote debugging as well as more seamless debugging
environments with IDEs not compatible with patched threads.

Change-Id: Idd4485b405cf0707781aa1250819a2140ee74550

commit_message:
Neutron pydevd debugger support

That patch allows a developer to remotely run a pydev debugger and having the
Neutron process connect back to it.

The implementation is similar to the one found in the Keystone or glance
project.

Four configuration options have been added:

    pydev-debug-host <host>. Default is None
    pydev-debug-port <port>. Default is None
    standard-threads (bool): Do not monkey-patch threading system modules.
    no-standard-threads (bool): inverse of --standard-threads. This is the
                             default behavior.

The behavior is enabled if `pydev-debug-host` *and* `pydev-debug-port` are
both not None.

Example:

1. neutron connecting back to pydevd using standard threads

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 12345

2. neutron connection back to pydevd using patched threads

   --pydev-debug-host 1.2.3.4 --pydev-debug-port 12345 --no-standard-threads

If the behavior is enabled, an os.environ variable will be set to indicate
that the thread must not get monkey patched:
(http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-August/000794.html).
Then, the pydev connection will be performed by the server right when starting
after reading the configuration.

Minor modifications were required to deal with the multiple calls to the
eventlet monkey patcher in multiple places throughout the Neutron code: a new
module in common has been defined performing the actual patch and
checking if whether or not standard threads are in use to discard thread patch
calls. Calls to eventlet monkey patcher have been changed to leverage this new
module throughout the Neutron code.

`standard-threads` option can be enabled independently of the pydev debug
options using the configuration options or by simply setting up an
environment variable called `STANDARD_THREADS`.

If the pydev connection fails to be established with the remote debugger an
exception is raised.

This patch will allow remote debugging as well as more seamless debugging
environments with IDEs not compatible with patched threads.

Change-Id: Idd4485b405cf0707781aa1250819a2140ee74550

commit_message:
Extend security-group API to allow security-groups auditing

blueprint security-group-auditing-api

APIImpact

Change-Id: Iadd7f92e166a69569a884a7e8d1064388336d9e5
Co-Authored-By: Gal Sagie <gal.sagie@huawei.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron-specs refs/changes/78/180078/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Security Group Auditing ========================================== There are currently two blueprints proposals concerning the subject [1]_ [2]_, In order to simplify review and discussion, we'll try to get aggrement on the required API change in this spec. https://blueprints.launchpad.net/neutron/+spec/security-group-auditing-api Problem Description =================== Current security-group API does not expose any way to control auditing of security-groups, this makes it hard for the user to debug connectivity problems or security holes and get full visbility of the environment. Auditing is an important aspect in firewalls/security implmentations and Neutron should support a way to enable it. Proposed Change =============== The proposed change is to extend the security-groups API in order to provide basic control over security-group auditing/logging, such an API can be used by any backend implementaion to provide security-group auditing. The suggested API will be limited to admin use only, this will be enforced with the Nuetron policy.json file, future implementation may expose it to other users, or even based on RBAC permissions [3]_. With the new API, admin user will be able to enable audit of a security-group using CLI:: neutron security-group-update <security-group-name> --audit True or using the API (see the API impact section). This spec does not propose any specific implementation, different backends might support different sets of auditing capabilities, one might only be capable to log security-groups events to a file on the host, where other might support more sophisticated ways to log audit events. To simplify things at first stage we propose a simple reference implementation which will only log the rule drop/allow statistics Future ideas for reference implementation improvement like: 1) Exporting the logs using syslog to an external entity or to the neutron-server 2) Using Celiometer to fetch the logs/events and display them ([2]_) Data Model Impact ----------------- A new Boolean column "audit" will be added to the 'securitygroups' table, the new column will indicate whether events on this security-group are audited or not. +----------+--------+--------+---------+------------+---------------+ |Attribute |Type |Access |Default |Validation/ |Description | |Name | | |Value |Conversion | | +==========+========+========+=========+============+===============+ |audit |boolean |RW,admin|'False' |boolean |Auditing the | | | | | | |security-group | +----------+--------+--------+---------+------------+---------------+ REST API Impact --------------- POST /v2.0/security-groups {"security_group": {"name": "My SG", "audit": "true"}} PUT /v2.0/security-groups/<security-group-id> {"security_group": {"audit": "true"}} Security Impact --------------- N/A Notifications Impact -------------------- N/A Other End User Impact --------------------- No changes to openstack-neutronclient are needed. Performance Impact ------------------ Auditing/Logging of rules usually have performance impact on the backend implementation. This should be considered at each of the implementations, this spec only tackle the API change to enable this feature IPv6 Impact ----------- N/A Other Deployer Impact --------------------- N/A Developer Impact ---------------- N/A Community Impact ---------------- N/A Alternatives ------------ Allow auditing control per security-group rule for better control granularity. This will require much more work on implementation, of the API and the reference implementation, can be added in the future (without breaking the current proposed API) if needed. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Roey Chen (roeyc) Gal Sagie (gsagie) Work Items ---------- - Implement the new API (extend model, db migration) - Write API tests - Centralized efforts for reference implementation Dependencies ============ None. Testing ======= Tempest Tests ------------- No plan to add new tests. Functional Tests ---------------- None, backend implementaion is not part of this blueprint. API Tests --------- API tests will be implemented as part of this blueprint. Documentation Impact ==================== The propose API is intended for use of the admin, relevant documentation should be updated. User Documentation ------------------ None Developer Documentation ----------------------- None References ========== .. [1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/132134/ .. [2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/169784/ .. [3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/132661/

commit_message:
acceptance/eventlet: simplify netstat testing

Our current gate runs both WSGI & Eventlet tests on the same node, and
the order seems random.

That means WSGI can runs first and eventlet second. In that order,
during the second phase, apache won't be stopped so keystone-server
won't start so the binding will be the same as apache/wsgi.

This patch use the same way as WSGI tests to try 5000 and 35357 binding
for Keystone API service.

Change-Id: I7fb6765b3cd130397ebf803dfd82e68be54e8672

commit_message:
functionnal: fix gating

Since devstack creates endpoint with v3 API, "openstack endpoint list"
returns a empty list, see:

  https://bugs.launchpad.net/keystone/+bug/1470635

This change is a workaround to this.

Change-Id: I1c406446ceea35df9ab33f98cebdadb59cd7ceef

subject: Handle attempts to "filter" list() calls by globally unique IDs
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-12 21:29:50.000000000', 'files': ['keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/test_domains.py', 'keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/test_role_assignments.py', 'keystoneclient/base.py', 'keystoneclient/v3/contrib/federation/protocols.py', 'keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/test_federation.py', 'keystoneclient/tests/unit/v3/utils.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient/commit/a423dc5ff875c6b8194d7b6ecf7f73696367990d', 'message': 'Handle attempts to "filter" list() calls by globally unique IDs

This use case isn't covered by our current APIs:

  GET /entities?id={entity_id}

Because we have a dedicated API for that:

  GET /entities/{entity_id}

But our list() methods generally support **kwargs, which are passed as
query parameters to keystone. When an 'id' is passed to keystone as a
query parameter, keystone rightly ignores it and returns an unfiltered
collection.

To provide the expected user experience, this change swaps calls like
list(id=...) with [get(id)] instead, which calls the correct HTTP API.

Change-Id: Id00fda97ce3308b1a228d62b0393594dd0526c43
Closes-Bug: 1452298
'}]
commit_message:
Handle attempts to "filter" list() calls by globally unique IDs

This use case isn't covered by our current APIs:

  GET /entities?id={entity_id}

Because we have a dedicated API for that:

  GET /entities/{entity_id}

But our list() methods generally support **kwargs, which are passed as
query parameters to keystone. When an 'id' is passed to keystone as a
query parameter, keystone rightly ignores it and returns an unfiltered
collection.

To provide the expected user experience, this change swaps calls like
list(id=...) with [get(id)] instead, which calls the correct HTTP API.

Change-Id: Id00fda97ce3308b1a228d62b0393594dd0526c43
Closes-Bug: 1452298
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-keystoneclient refs/changes/59/182459/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_list_by_id(self, ref=None, expected_path=None, **filter_kwargs): """Test ``entities.list(id=x)`` being rewritten as ``GET /v3/entities/x``. This tests an edge case of each manager's list() implementation, to ensure that it "does the right thing" when users call ``.list()`` when they should have used ``.get()``. """ ref = ref or self.new_ref() if not expected_path: expected_path = self._get_expected_path(expected_path) expected_path += '/%s' % ref['id'] self.requests_mock.get(urlparse.urljoin(self.TEST_URL, expected_path), json=self.encode(ref)) if 'id' not in filter_kwargs: filter_kwargs['id'] = ref['id'] returned_list = self.manager.list(**filter_kwargs) self.assertEqual(1, len(returned_list)) returned_ref = returned_list[0] for attr in ref.keys(): self.assertEqual( getattr(returned_ref, attr), ref[attr], 'Expected different %s' % attr)

commit_message:
Load services from entry_points

This change was started by Donald Stufft, and allows us to dynamically
load services via setuptools entry_points instead of hard coding into
the Profile.

CURRENTLY HAS NO TESTS - this is just reviving it from a github branch
for right now as a work-in-progress

Change-Id: I6100303cfdbae7929512ec1fc6b0bd7e68eef66d

commit_message:
Improving statistics sent to Graphite.

Currently, the statistics are organized by command. However, it would also be useful
to know statistics organized by policy because different policies may be based on
different storage properties (ie, faster disks).
With this change, all the statistics for object timers will be sent per policy as well.

Change-Id: Ib48106a18f4dad13f098970a6ebc45f363633a33
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/73/200373/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from swift.common.storage_policy import POLICIES metric_name_policy = self.statsd_metric_name_policy(req, status_int, method, policy_index) if metric_name_policy: self.access_logger.timing(metric_name_policy + '.timing', (end_time - start_time) * 1000) self.access_logger.update_stats(metric_name_policy + '.xfer', bytes_received + bytes_sent) def get_metric_name_type(self, req): return stat_type def statsd_metric_name(self, req, status_int, method): stat_type = self.get_metric_name_type(req) def statsd_metric_name_policy(self, req, status_int, method, policy_index): stat_type = self.get_metric_name_type(req) policy_name = POLICIES.get_by_index(policy_index).name if stat_type == 'object': stat_method = method if method in self.valid_methods \ else 'BAD_METHOD' return '.'.join((stat_type, 'policy', policy_name, stat_method, str(status_int))) else: return None policy_index = get_policy_index(req.headers, resp_headers) metric_name_policy = self.statsd_metric_name_policy(req, status_int, method, policy_index) if metric_name_policy: self.access_logger.timing_since( metric_name_policy + '.first-byte.timing', start_time)

commit_message:
Fix failure to create glance https connection pool

Due to a typo in an attribute named, an Attribute error is raised
causing failure in connection to glance through HTTPS

Urllib3 PoolManager class has a connection_pool_kw attribute
but not connection_kw

Closes-Bug: #1479020
Change-Id: Id4d6a5bdcf971d09e80043fd2ab399e208fd931c

commit_message:
RHEL registration shouldn't use attach with activation key

In the case of using portal registration with an
activation key, the RHEL registration script is still
executing a `subscription-manager attach` command. This
should not happen if an activation key is provided. This
is because an activation key already provides the
subscriptions to attach.

Change-Id: I2907bede28a9b7bef71cedeea69c876eb4949df0

commit_message:
Add unit test for method list_keypairs

This patch adds unit test for keypairs_client.
Specific about method list_keypairs.

Change-Id: I7879280ff4f0211c7ec59c7225183f39978d3d41
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/85/204385/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import httplib2 from oslotest import mockpatch from tempest.services.compute.json import keypairs_client from tempest.tests import base from tempest.tests import fake_auth_provider from tempest.tests import fake_config class TestKeyPairsClient(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestKeyPairsClient, self).setUp() self.useFixture(fake_config.ConfigFixture()) fake_auth = fake_auth_provider.FakeAuthProvider() self.client = keypairs_client.KeyPairsClient( fake_auth, 'compute', 'regionOne') def _test_list_keypairs(self, bytes_body=False): body = '{"keypairs": []}' if bytes_body: body = bytes(body.encode('utf-8')) expected = [] response = (httplib2.Response({'status': 200}), body) self.useFixture(mockpatch.Patch( 'tempest.common.service_client.ServiceClient.get', return_value=response)) self.assertEqual(expected, self.client.list_keypairs()) def test_list_keypairs_with_str_body(self): self._test_list_keypairs() def test_list_keypairs_with_bytes_body(self): self._test_list_keypairs(bytes_body=True)

commit_message:
Add a loop to git_prune

git remote prune is sometimes hitting the same "GnuTLS recv error (-9):
A TLS packet with unexpected length was received" error that git remote
update was hitting in bug 1383403.

This change takes the timeout/retry logic in git_remote_update and puts
it into it's own git_timed method (sort of like the one in devstack)
so both git_remote_update and git_prune can leverage it.

Closes-Bug: #1455123

Change-Id: I026499c58baf5db644786b0cb4c6d04a5c70f7ae
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/24/183124/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Attempt a git remote prune. Run for up to 5 minutes before killing. # If first SIGTERM does not kill the process wait a minute then SIGKILL. # If update fails try again for up to a total of 3 attempts. MAX_ATTEMPTS=3 COUNT=0 until timeout -k 1m 5m git remote prune origin; do COUNT=$(($COUNT + 1)) echo "git remote prune origin failed." if [ $COUNT -eq $MAX_ATTEMPTS ]; then echo "Max attempts reached for git remote prune origin; giving up." exit 1 fi SLEEP_TIME=$((30 + $RANDOM % 60)) echo "sleep $SLEEP_TIME before retrying." sleep $SLEEP_TIME done

added_lines: """Create a file object :param container: The name of the container to store the file in. This container will be created if it does not exist already. :param name: Name for the object within the container. :param filename: The local file whose contents will be uploaded. which is up (true, default) or down (false). (Optional) :param md5: A hexadecimal md5 of the file. (Optional), if it is known and can be passed here, it will save repeating the expensive md5 process. :param sha256: A hexadecimal md5 of the file. ( Optional) See md5. :param segment_size: Break the uploaded object into segments of this many bytes. (Optional) Shade will attempt to discover the maximum value for this from the server if it is not specified, or will use a reasonable default. :param headers: These will be passed through to the object creation API as HTTP Headers. :raises: ``OpenStackCloudException`` on operation error. """

commit_message:
Create a repository for stackforge/xstatic-bootswatch

Bootswatch provides many out of the box Bootstrap themes.
We plan on using this in Horizon to provide a theme that
implements Google's Material Design.  This patch creates
a repo for it.

Change-Id: I64278f797b79a53b35212c6564fd0d1ae8b7978c

commit_message:
Templateize and change Galera SST method

Per the bug we need to be using xtrabackup-v2 for the wsrep_sst_method.  This
patch creates an galera_sst_method variable and defaults it to xtrabackup-v2.

Change-Id: Iee88b49e84e3a8aaf477af45b4a42a4a2c31634e
Closes-Bug: 1478105
(cherry picked from commit 6f170025e6f32b9a80bfd1efee627eea3d97f267)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/82/207082/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## sst method galera_sst_method: xtrabackup-v2

commit_message:
Perform port_rescan on s390x platforms

When adding Fibre-Channel block storage on Linux on System z and
auto-port scanning has been turned off, Fibre-channel target ports need
to be added explicitely by OpenStack. If this is not done, OpenStack
will fail to add volumes.

Closes-Bug: #1475648

Change-Id: I4a8c9ee256add1ddd27359f42f4a97b45aebebcd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-brick refs/changes/26/203026/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import os If auto-discovery of Fibre-Channel target ports is disabled on s390 platforms, ports need to be added to the configuration. filepath = ("/sys/bus/ccw/drivers/zfcp/%s/%s" % (device_number, target_wwn)) if not (os.path.exists(filepath)): zfcp_device_command = ("/sys/bus/ccw/drivers/zfcp/%s/port_rescan" % (device_number)) LOG.debug("port_rescan call for s390: %s", zfcp_device_command) try: self.echo_scsi_command(zfcp_device_command, "1") except putils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: LOG.warning(_LW("port_rescan call for s390 failed exit" " %(code)s, stderr %(stderr)s"), {'code': exc.exit_code, 'stderr': exc.stderr})

subject: Revert "Fix trove-functional-dsvm-gate tests"
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-29 13:52:54.000000000', 'files': ['scripts/redstack'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration/commit/bf0074a2ecace28a33ce9d8142cf91902beaa635', 'message': 'Revert "Fix trove-functional-dsvm-gate tests"

This reverts commit fd52298c7911f92eb8930fe1a8cff0f3798f2967

This assumes that the version of openstackclient being used
has the -c and -f options, which is not true in stable/kilo
where osc is capped at 1.0.4.

If this project is going to be branchless it should be
gated against stable compat jobs like Tempest is so we
don't regress stable branches by changes which only have
master in mind.

Change-Id: I3fd9726765c6b7e785a6f7d561918a5673add380
Closes-Bug: #1479358
'}]
commit_message:
Revert "Fix trove-functional-dsvm-gate tests"

This reverts commit fd52298c7911f92eb8930fe1a8cff0f3798f2967

This assumes that the version of openstackclient being used
has the -c and -f options, which is not true in stable/kilo
where osc is capped at 1.0.4.

If this project is going to be branchless it should be
gated against stable compat jobs like Tempest is so we
don't regress stable branches by changes which only have
master in mind.

Change-Id: I3fd9726765c6b7e785a6f7d561918a5673add380
Closes-Bug: #1479358
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/54/207054/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: SWIFT_ENDPOINT=$(openstack endpoint list | grep 'swift' | get_field 1) openstack endpoint create swift --region RegionOne --publicurl 'http://'$NETWORK_GATEWAY':8080/v1/AUTH_$(tenant_id)s' \ --internalurl 'http://'$NETWORK_GATEWAY':8080/v1/AUTH_$(tenant_id)s' --adminurl 'http://'$NETWORK_GATEWAY':8080' openstack endpoint delete $SWIFT_ENDPOINT
deleted_lines: SWIFT_ENDPOINTS=$(openstack endpoint list --os-url http://$NETWORK_GATEWAY:5000/v3 --os-identity-api-version=3 --service swift -c ID -f value) openstack endpoint create --os-url http://$NETWORK_GATEWAY:5000/v3 --os-identity-api-version=3 swift public 'http://'$NETWORK_GATEWAY':8080/v1/AUTH_$(tenant_id)s' --region RegionOne openstack endpoint create --os-url http://$NETWORK_GATEWAY:5000/v3 --os-identity-api-version=3 swift internal 'http://'$NETWORK_GATEWAY':8080/v1/AUTH_$(tenant_id)s' --region RegionOne openstack endpoint create --os-url http://$NETWORK_GATEWAY:5000/v3 --os-identity-api-version=3 swift admin 'http://'$NETWORK_GATEWAY':8080' --region RegionOne echo $SWIFT_ENDPOINTS | xargs -n 1 openstack endpoint delete --os-url http://$NETWORK_GATEWAY:5000/v3 --os-identity-api-version=3

Fix repo section in example config file

Fix repository target host section in the
openstack_user_config.yml.example to use repo-infra_hosts
instead of repo_hosts.

Closes-Bug: #1475116

commit_message:
Remove /opt/kolla directory creation base images

No need to do a make dir since COPY will create it.
Also removed from service specific base images since
it will not be required.

Change-Id: I15064eaf6e8faa9acbda68eaf3d85589ea9ed3d9
Closes-Bug: #1479176

commit_message:
Add unit test for method list_aggregates

This patch adds unit test for aggregates_client.
Specific about method list_aggregates.

Change-Id: If66b8f8688432e6bd28c7ab6a4d0551675ef5114
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/78/201978/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 NEC Corporation. All rights reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import httplib2 from oslotest import mockpatch from tempest.services.compute.json import aggregates_client from tempest.tests import base from tempest.tests import fake_auth_provider from tempest.tests import fake_config class TestAggregatesClient(base.TestCase): def setUp(self): super(TestAggregatesClient, self).setUp() self.useFixture(fake_config.ConfigFixture()) fake_auth = fake_auth_provider.FakeAuthProvider() self.client = aggregates_client.AggregatesClient(fake_auth, 'compute', 'regionOne') def _test_list_aggregates(self, bytes_body=False): if bytes_body: body = bytes(b'{"aggregates": []}') else: body = '{"aggregates": []}' expected = [] response = (httplib2.Response({'status': 200}), body) self.useFixture(mockpatch.Patch( 'tempest.common.service_client.ServiceClient.get', return_value=response)) self.assertEqual(expected, self.client.list_aggregates()) def test_list_aggregates_with_str_body(self): self._test_list_aggregates() def test_list_aggregates_with_bytes_body(self): self._test_list_aggregates(bytes_body=True)

commit_message:
Fix instance_exists uuid

When the uuid cache was removed it broke the instance_exists()
method because the instance uuid was no longer translated to
the PowerVM uuid value. The fix is to add back in that
translation that use to be done by the cache lookup().

Change-Id: I60c838a09f5cdd5f6b8212250ad3874403e6711d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-powervm refs/changes/72/207072/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix race in check and access of /dev/disk/by-path/

If udev deletes the directory between the check and access then we have
an exception thrown. Instead of checking, just list the directory and
handle the exception in case it doesn't exist.

Co-Authored-By: Jordan Pittier <jordan.pittier@scality.com>
Change-Id: I52143923d2407b3d43eccf5d3c51526a92d1e3c5
Closes-Bug: 1478473

commit_message:
Adds Google site master tracking code to index.html only

- Want to further improve Google search results using sitemaster tools.
- Make sure the meta info only lands in index.html and not in all pages on site.

Change-Id: I3b63ea64c639060b9f6893e88df4bb777a7c8064

commit_message:
Rename 2 files and Fix 19 typos on Cloud Admin Guide and Config Ref

fix following one word, it affects two filename and 19 words.
weighter => weigher
This fix affects following documents.
  Cloud Administrator Guide
  Configuration Reference

http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/content/section_manage-volumes.html
http://docs.openstack.org/admin-guide-cloud/content/volume_number_weighter.html

http://docs.openstack.org/draft/config-reference/content/compute-nova-conf.html

This issue is already discussed on following thread in ML.
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-docs/2015-July/007184.html

Change-Id: Ib5e652b454b613e3851765726647d62ce01f8b0f
Closes-Bug: #1478507

subject: Auto-collect app/ instead of only app/core/
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-24 22:53:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/e8fbc011a22f577448668f3c8debcffd03d3d92a', 'message': "Auto-collect app/ instead of only app/core/

Angular code for openstack_dashboard is almost finished
migrating to openstack_dashboard/static/app/.

Previously, the root module of app (app.module.js) was explicitly
included from _conf.html so that environment variables from Django
could be captured in the 'horizon.app.conf' constant.

This prevented auto-collection at the static/app/ level because
app.module.js will be included twice (once from _conf.html, and
again during auto-collection)

It turns out that 'horizon.app.conf' is unnecessary as an Angular
constant. It's only use is to initialize the 'horizon.conf' global
provided by horizon.js.

This patch refactors _conf.html to directly initialize horizon.conf.
This removes the need for app.module.js to be included from
_conf.html, which allows us to change the auto-collection directory
to 'app/'.

Now all files in horizon/static and openstack_dashboard/static/app
are auto-collected, without including app.module.js twice. All new
angular files are expected to live in one of these two locations,
minimizing changes to static_settings.py to include new files for
auto-collection

Change-Id: I95b6f13c85eb08c875885812a7db054a5aa6e7c2
Partial-Bug: 1458697
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-07-24 23:49:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/horizon/commit/99ecaac0577acd4941497194ee5477d1b7ba2aac', 'message': "Auto-collect app/ instead of only app/core/

commit_message:
Auto-collect app/ instead of only app/core/

Angular code for openstack_dashboard is almost finished
migrating to openstack_dashboard/static/app/.

Previously, the root module of app (app.module.js) was explicitly
included from _conf.html so that environment variables from Django
could be captured in the 'horizon.app.conf' constant.

This prevented auto-collection at the static/app/ level because
app.module.js will be included twice (once from _conf.html, and
again during auto-collection)

It turns out that 'horizon.app.conf' is unnecessary as an Angular
constant. It's only use is to initialize the 'horizon.conf' global
provided by horizon.js.

This patch refactors _conf.html to directly initialize horizon.conf.
This removes the need for app.module.js to be included from
_conf.html, which allows us to change the auto-collection directory
to 'app/'.

Now all files in horizon/static and openstack_dashboard/static/app
are auto-collected, without including app.module.js twice. All new
angular files are expected to live in one of these two locations,
minimizing changes to static_settings.py to include new files for
auto-collection

Change-Id: I95b6f13c85eb08c875885812a7db054a5aa6e7c2
Partial-Bug: #1458697
Closes-Bug: #1477825

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-16 14:12:18.000000000', 'files': ['playbooks/galera-install.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/57577bb369a107ed704f4791090b1c810599258c', 'message': 'Remove {{ from "with_items" and "when" statements

This patch resolves a minor issue that was generating a "warning"
message when running the galera-install.yml playbook.

The "{{" and "}}" are not required for conditionals, and loop
expressions, so these can and should safely be removed from "when:"
statements and "with_items:" statements.

Functionality does not change but the warning message will go away after

Change-Id: I3e9d3a4afb0e3d1284c78a37dba6d1534154a063
Closes-Bug: #1475328
'}]
commit_message:
Remove {{ from "with_items" and "when" statements

This patch resolves a minor issue that was generating a "warning"
message when running the galera-install.yml playbook.

The "{{" and "}}" are not required for conditionals, and loop
expressions, so these can and should safely be removed from "when:"
statements and "with_items:" statements.

Functionality does not change but the warning message will go away after
this patch.

Change-Id: I3e9d3a4afb0e3d1284c78a37dba6d1534154a063
Closes-Bug: #1475328

commit_message:
Cleanup unused functions in swift_rings.py

Removes 2 unused functions in swift_rings.py (check_section &
has_section), these are not called at all and should be removed for
clarity.

Change-Id: Id56654df92834f7a48ce21e70b372f04e920653e
Closes-Bug: #1474334
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/31/201531/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def has_section(conf, section): return True if conf.get(section) else False def check_section(conf, section): if not has_section(conf, section): print("Section %s doesn't exist" % section) sys.exit(2)

subject: CORS Support for OpenStack
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-05-04 18:41:36.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs/commit/73a55eb8e0131396a15fd7ca92d5337dc94c6193', 'message': "CORS Support for OpenStack

This specification details implementing the W3C's Cross Origin
Resource Sharing specification in openstack's API's. It is intended
to provide additional options to user interface projects, by
permitting the API's to selectively break the single-origin policy
for configurable domains. It makes use of a single, common
middleware implementation already available in oslo_middleware.

Change-Id: I2135043f49f64b096b6bd295966d2e73697c7764
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2015-05-06 21:22:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs/commit/8604ffd1b476cb02aa0ba194f3591312251f6850', 'message': "CORS Support for OpenStack

This specification details implementing the W3C's Cross Origin
Resource Sharing specification in openstack's API's. It is intended
to provide additional options to user interface projects, by
permitting the API's to selectively break the single-origin policy
for configurable domains. It makes use of a single, common

commit_message:
CORS Support for OpenStack

This specification details implementing the W3C's Cross Origin
Resource Sharing specification in openstack's API's. It is intended
to provide additional options to user interface projects, by
permitting the API's to selectively break the single-origin policy
for configurable domains. It makes use of a single, common
middleware implementation already available in oslo_middleware.

Change-Id: I2135043f49f64b096b6bd295966d2e73697c7764
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-specs refs/changes/66/179866/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ============ CORS Support ============ The W3C has released a Technical Recommendation (TR) via which an API may permit a user agent - usually a web browser - to selectively break the `same-origin policy`_. This permits javascript running in the user agent to access the API from domains, protocols, and ports that do not match the API itself. This TR is called Cross Origin Resource Sharing (CORS_). This specification details how CORS_ is implemented and supported across OpenStack's services. Problem description =================== User Agents (browsers), in order to limit Cross-Site Scripting exploits, do not permit access to an API that does not match the hostname, protocol, and port from which the javascript itself is hosted. For example, if a user agent's javascript is hosted at `https://example.com:443/`, and tries to access openstack ironic at `https://example.com:6354/`, it would not be permitted to do so because the ports do not match. This is called the `same-origin policy`_. The `default ports`_ for most openstack services (excluding horizon) are not the ports commonly used by user agents to access websites (80, 443). As such, even if the services were hosted on the same domain and protocol, it would be impossible for any user agent's application to access these services directly, as any request would violate the above policy. The current method of addressing this is to provide an API proxy, currently part of the horizon project, which is accessible from the same location as any javascript that might wish to access it. This additional code requires additional maintenance for both upstream and downstream teams, and is largely unnecessary. This specification does _not_ presume to require an additional configuration step for operators for a 'default' install of OpenStack and its user interface. Horizon currently maintains, and shall continue to maintain, its own installation requirements. This specification does _not_ presume to set front-end application design standards- rather it exists to expand the options that front-end teams have, and allow them to make whatever choice makes the most sense for them. This specification _does_ provide a method by which teams, whether upstream or downstream, can choose to implement additional user interfaces of their own. An example use case may be Ironic, which may wish to ship an interface that can live independently of horizon, for such users who do not want to install additional components. Proposed change =============== All OpenStack API's should implement a common middleware that implements CORS in a reusable, optional fashion. This middleware should be well documented, with security concerns highlighted, in order to properly educate the operator community on their choices. `CORS Middleware`_ is available in oslo_middleware version 0.3.0. Additional work would be required to add this middleware to the appropriate services, and to add the necessary documentation to the docs repository. Note that improperly implemented CORS_ support is a security concern, and this should be highlighted in the documentation. Alternatives ------------ One alternative is to provide a stripped down proxy, much like horizon's implementation, as an starter project template. It would require additional documentation that teaches UI development teams on how to implement and build on it. This mostly already exists inside of horizon, and could be repurposed. Implementation ============== Assignee -------- Primary assignee: Michael Krotscheck (krotscheck) Work Items ---------- - Update Global Requirements to use oslo_middleware version 1.2.0 - Add `CORS Middleware`_ to OpenStack API's - Nova - Swift - Glance - Neutron - Cinder - Keystone - Celiometer - Heat - Trove - Sahara - Ironic - Write documentation for CORS configuration, security concerns, et al. Dependencies ============ - Depends on oslo_middleware version 1.2.0 History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Liberty - Introduced .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. _CORS: http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/ .. _`default ports`: http://docs.openstack.org/juno/config-reference/content/firewalls-default-ports.html .. _`Same-origin Policy`: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Same-origin_policy .. _`CORS Middleware`: http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.middleware/cors.html

commit_message:
Add spec for 'Enhance iSCSI volume multipath support'

This spec proposes to enhance iSCSI multipath support by defining the way for
get multiple iSCSI portals/iqns/luns to access a volume (LU) from Cinder.

Change-Id: I0b1f3f33c7f37abef56b4f12449180d314a4a922
blueprint: iscsi-multipath-enhancement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/99/134299/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Support iSCSI portal multipath ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/iscsi-portal-multipath This spec proposes to add multipath support of iSCSI portals of cinder volumes. Problem description =================== Currently, data path to iSCSI volumes supports multipath by setting libvirt driver's 'iscsi_use_multipath' config to True. However, if the primary iSCSI portal address becomes unaccessible due to network failure etc., nova-compute will fail to attach the volumes even if another address for the portal is online. To avoid this issue, Cinder will add secondary addresses of iSCSI portal into the response from 'initialize_connection' API. This spec proposes to enable nova to access the secondary addresses of iSCSI portal to discover the volumes. Proposed change =============== Cinder will pass the optional parameters 'target_portal_secondary', 'target_iqn_secondary', and 'target_lun_secondary' into 'connection_info' returned by os-initialize_connection volume action API, that represents a list of secondary addresses of the iSCSI portals and the corresponding iqn, lun to each portal. When 'iscsi_use_multipath' is enabled in nova.conf, nova-compute should send discovery query to every portal specified by these parameters to the targets. Even if a part of the portals are not responding, the connection process should be continued when the other are responding. Note that old version of nova-compute just ignores the new parameters, but it works without changes if the primary portal address is alive. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- None. Note that 'connection_info' JSON string with new parameters are stored in the table 'block_device_mapping', but it doesn't require changes of schema. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ None Other deployer impact --------------------- To enable this feature, 'iscsi_use_multipath' should be set to True in the [libvirt] section of nova.conf. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: tsekiyama Work Items ---------- - Implement this feature in Cinder - Modify nova and brick library to send discovery query to multiple portals Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= - Unit tests for connect_volume/disconnect_volume for iSCSI volumes should be added to check if they can handle response from initialize_connection volume API with and without new parameters. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== * Enable multipath for libvirt iSCSI Volume Driver (merged) https://review.openstack.org/#/c/17946/ * Cinder-specs: Support iSCSI portal multipath https://review.openstack.org/#/c/131502

commit_message:
libvirt: Enhance iSCSI volume multipath support

Currently, nova-compute supports multipath for iSCSI volume data
path. It depends on response to targets discovery from the main
iSCSI portal, expecting multiple portal addresses to be contained.

However, some arrays only respond to discovery with a single portal
address, even if secondary portals are available. In this case,
nova-compute cannot know secondary portals and corresponding iSCSI
target IQN, so nova-compute cannot establish multiple sessions for
the target(s). To enable nova-compute to login to secondary portals,
Cinder's response to initialize_connection API will return
connection_info with multiple portal addresses/iqns/luns when
multipath=True is specifed in the connector info. For example:

  {"driver_volume_type": "iscsi",
   "data": {"target_portals": ["10.0.2.15:3260", "10.0.3.15:3260"],
            "target_iqns": ["iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-01",
                            "iqn.2010-10.org.example:target-02"],
            "target_luns": [1, 2],
            ...}}

Nova should try to login to every portal addresses/iqns/luns when
they are passed from cinder.

Change-Id: Iddd67d6b5b27ccc1e0a3963cbf7896b60da30b01
Implements: blueprint iscsi-multipath-enhancement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/83/134683/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_libvirt_iscsi_driver_with_secondary_portal(self): libvirt_driver = volume.LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver(self.fake_conn) location2 = '10.0.3.15:3260' iqn2 = self.iqn + '-2' devs = ['/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-1' % (self.location, self.iqn), '/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-2' % (location2, iqn2)] mpdev = '/dev/mapper/fake-multipath-devname' with contextlib.nested( mock.patch.object(os.path, 'exists', return_value=True), mock.patch.object(self.fake_conn, '_get_all_block_devices', return_value=devs), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_rescan_multipath'), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_run_multipath'), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_get_multipath_device_name', return_value=mpdev), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_get_multipath_iqn', return_value=[self.iqn, iqn2]), ) as (mock_exists, mock_devices, mock_rescan_multipath, mock_run_multipath, mock_device_name, mock_get_iqn): libvirt_driver.use_multipath = True vol = {'id': 1, 'name': self.name} connection_info = self.iscsi_connection(vol, self.location, self.iqn) connection_info['data']['target_portal_secondary'] = [location2] connection_info['data']['target_iqn_secondary'] = [iqn2] connection_info['data']['target_lun_secondary'] = [2] libvirt_driver.connect_volume(connection_info, self.disk_info) self.assertEqual(mpdev, connection_info['data']['device_path']) expected_commands = [('iscsiadm', '-m', 'node', '-T', self.iqn, '-p', self.location, '--login'), ('iscsiadm', '-m', 'node', '-T', iqn2, '-p', location2, '--login')] for command in expected_commands: self.assertIn(command, self.executes) mock_device_name.assert_called_once_with(devs[0]) self.executes = [] libvirt_driver.disconnect_volume(connection_info, "vde") expected_commands = [('iscsiadm', '-m', 'node', '-T', self.iqn, '-p', self.location, '--logout'), ('iscsiadm', '-m', 'node', '-T', iqn2, '-p', location2, '--logout')] for command in expected_commands: self.assertIn(command, self.executes) def test_libvirt_iscsi_driver_with_secondary_portal_primary_error(self): libvirt_driver = volume.LibvirtISCSIVolumeDriver(self.fake_conn) location2 = '10.0.3.15:3260' iqn2 = self.iqn + '-2' dev1 = '/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-1' % (self.location, self.iqn) dev2 = '/dev/disk/by-path/ip-%s-iscsi-%s-lun-2' % (location2, iqn2) mpdev = '/dev/mapper/fake-multipath-devname' def fake_run_iscsiadm(iscsi_properties, iscsi_command, **kwargs): if iscsi_properties['target_portal'] == self.location: if iscsi_command == ('--login',): raise processutils.ProcessExecutionError(None, None, 21) return mock.DEFAULT with contextlib.nested( mock.patch.object(os.path, 'exists', side_effect=lambda x: x != dev1), mock.patch.object(self.fake_conn, '_get_all_block_devices', return_value=[dev2]), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_rescan_multipath'), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_run_multipath'), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_get_multipath_device_name', return_value=mpdev), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_get_multipath_iqn', return_value=[iqn2]), mock.patch.object(libvirt_driver, '_run_iscsiadm', side_effect=fake_run_iscsiadm), ) as (mock_exists, mock_devices, mock_rescan_multipath, mock_run_multipath, mock_device_name, mock_get_iqn, mock_iscsiadm): libvirt_driver.use_multipath = True vol = {'id': 1, 'name': self.name} connection_info = self.iscsi_connection(vol, self.location, self.iqn) connection_info['data']['target_portal_secondary'] = [location2] connection_info['data']['target_iqn_secondary'] = [iqn2] connection_info['data']['target_lun_secondary'] = [2] props = connection_info['data'].copy() libvirt_driver.connect_volume(connection_info, self.disk_info) self.assertEqual(mpdev, connection_info['data']['device_path']) mock_device_name.assert_called_once_with(dev2) mock_iscsiadm.assert_any_call(props, ('--login',), check_exit_code=[0, 255]) props['target_portal'] = location2 props['target_iqn'] = iqn2 mock_iscsiadm.assert_any_call(props, ('--login',), check_exit_code=[0, 255]) mock_iscsiadm.reset_mock() libvirt_driver.disconnect_volume(connection_info, "vde") props = connection_info['data'].copy() mock_iscsiadm.assert_any_call(props, ('--logout',), check_exit_code=[0, 21, 255]) props['target_portal'] = location2 props['target_iqn'] = iqn2 mock_iscsiadm.assert_any_call(props, ('--logout',), check_exit_code=[0, 21, 255])

commit_message:
Support deliverables in milestone.sh

Neutron is no longer a special case: multiple other project teams
use deliverables which will result in multiple tarballs to be
uploaded to the same Launchpad page.

Change-Id: Iae373f620bfa09dd6cf134e25aa7dcf942af78eb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/release-tools refs/changes/23/206523/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "Usage: $0 milestone SHA project [deliverable]"DELIVERABLE=$4if [[ "$DELIVERABLE" != "" ]]; then echo "Extra element in $DELIVERABLE deliverable" echo "Skipping bugs updates and upload to $DELIVERABLE LP page" LPROJECT="$DELIVERABLE"
deleted_lines: echo "Usage: $0 milestone SHA project"if [[ "$PROJECT" == neutron-* ]]; then echo "Neutron advanced services mode: skipping bugs and upload to neutron" LPROJECT="neutron"

commit_message:
Log which service is down

This changes the message "Manager for service cinder-volume
is reporting problems..." to
"Manager for service cinder-volume myhost@backend1 is
reporting problems..."

This makes it more clear in the log file which backend this
message is referring to.

Change-Id: I62172080084a01c0324ffb6ab8a0e4af2b47fb85
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/11/206211/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: LOG.error(_LE('Manager for service %s is reporting problems, skip ' 'sending heartbeat. Service will appear "down".'), self.binary)

commit_message:
Straighten up keystone endpoint management

In chasing why I couldn't get keystone client commands to work on
projects in unitedstack, it turns out we were constructing the
keystoneclient Client wrong- and many other clients. Make sure we're
passing endpoint_type and region_name in the correct places.

This needs to be checked - apparently different Client objects take
interface or endpoint_type. The future wants to be "interface"

Change-Id: I3a4d02fcbcee678e98738ef35779454119b6d108

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-07-22 08:38:35.000000000', 'files': ['shade/meta.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/shade/commit/da85cbfadfd5a11a077ce79dc3b59b1b585ce06d', 'message': "Fix shade returning empty private_v4

Change-Id: I1b52fe137237119c9b80b976136ace94581d4d70
"}]
commit_message:
Fix shade returning empty private_v4

The code just assumed all clouds will contain networks being
'private' and 'public'.
That's not the case for HP Cloud, where networks will contain
the Neutron network names the instance is attached to.

Change-Id: I1b52fe137237119c9b80b976136ace94581d4d70

commit_message:
Set default inventory file for inventory-manage.py

The script inventory-manage.py takes a file argument. The default name
for this file, in the project, is openstack_inventory.json. Not only is
it the default but the rest of the project assumes that it will be that
name.

This commit sets the default argument for the file parameter to this
assumed file name - 'openstack_inventory.json'.

Change-Id: I635122d22bb0467aad21f48dccda1bc0444518c1
Closes-bug: #1454324
(cherry picked from commit 576831481262b93dfdf72f078a4b620a7ac130fb)

deleted_lines: :param user_file: ``str`` Additional localtion to look in FIRST for a file required=True, default=None
